title_review: Good Dancing. Terrible Food. Very Expensive.
review_preview: My wife and I just went to Corral de la Morreria last night. I'm not someone who writes a lot of reviews but felt compelled after our experience. When making reservations you have the option of going to the 8:00 show with dinner or the...
review_full: My wife and I just went to Corral de la Morreria last night. I'm not someone who writes a lot of reviews but felt compelled after our experience. When making reservations you have the option of going to the 8:00 show with dinner or the midnight show and have drinks. We chose the dinner show because midnight was a little too late for us. After being seated, we took a look at the dinner menu. I expected the prices to be a little outrageous since it's basically a dinner theatre and a huge tourist attraction, but that didn't even prepare me for the sticker shock I felt. Hoping that the food was going to be wonderful (which I should have known better) we enjoyed a bottle of wine and waited for our food. When it arrived, my wife's lobster was barely cooked and sent it back, my food was OK at best. It's pretty sad when you spend 138 Euros on dinner (not including the tickets to the show) and all your thinking about is where is the closest McDonalds when the show is over. The service was poor, no one checked in on us to see if the 2nd attempt on the lobster was satisfactory. Right when I was trying my hardest to stay optimistic, hoping that the show would make me forget about the bad food, a bunch of people started flowing in at the last minute to fill up all of the seats. None of these people ordered food and basically got in to see the early show without spending nearly the same amount of money as us. The dancing was great, and very entertaining, but overall the show didn't make up for the short-comings.

review_preview: When I decided to study abroad in Spain, I wanted to experience as much Spanish culture as possible. Naturally Flamenco was something I wanted to see. I happened to go to El Corral de la Moreria and I highly recommend it! It is the oldest...
review_full: When I decided to study abroad in Spain, I wanted to experience as much Spanish culture as possible. Naturally Flamenco was something I wanted to see. I happened to go to El Corral de la Moreria and I highly recommend it! It is the oldest and most famous tablao in Madrid and it is well known among celebrates and royalty, such as Natalie Portman, Frank Sinatra, the King and Queen of Spain, Ernest Hemingway and many more. And the flamenco was amazing! The entire audience was enraptured from the first notes of the spanish guitar to the final stomp of the flamenco dancer¬¥s heel. Before the show started, my friend and I ate an amazing dinner! I had roasted vegetables, leg of lamb and sorbet. It was the best food I have tasted since I left my home and my mother¬¥s home cooking (she is an amazing cook). Although it is not a cheap experience, flamenco at El Corral de la Moreria is definitely something everyone should experience at least once in their life!

title_review: Amazing Dancing - Lousy Food and Service
review_preview: We were in Madrid on our honeymoon in March and had been told how wonderful the flamenco dancing was at Corral De La Moreria.  As we were going to meet up with some friends later, we made reservations for the early show, planning to have...
review_full: We were in Madrid on our honeymoon in March and had been told how wonderful the flamenco dancing was at Corral De La Moreria. As we were going to meet up with some friends later, we made reservations for the early show, planning to have dinner there as well. BIG MISTAKE. The place is a cattle car when it comes to packing people in. Every single nook and cranny is jammed with a table. We ordered our dinner - each of us had the paella figuring it was a specialty of the house and how could you go wrong with paella. Wow, again, big mistake. The food was bland and uninspired. The service was almost non-existent.  I will say that the show was amazing. The costumes, intensity, and electricity of the dancers could be felt throughout the place (not hard I guess when you are packed in). Would we do it again? Not for dinner. Maybe just to see the show. Save your money.

title_review: Best dinner experience in Madrid. Authentic Spanish Tapas!
review_preview: We arrived in Madrid from Hong Kong and were very excited to try the local foods. We made our reservation online at 2pm on the same day and were very happy that we could book a table for 9:15pm (We recently found out Spanish people...
review_full: We arrived in Madrid from Hong Kong and were very excited to try the local foods. We made our reservation online at 2pm on the same day and were very happy that we could book a table for 9:15pm (We recently found out Spanish people eat at late times!) We arrived at the restaurant and were greeted by Delfina. She and the rest of the staff were super friendly and give us helpful food recommendations. We ordered the Patatas Bravas, Seabass Ceviche and freshly made Tortilla. If you like blue cheese, my girlfriend said that the Cabrales blue cheese with red pepper honey montaditos is the best blue cheese she has ever tasted. The food was very affordable, portion sizes were just right for sharing and the warm service from the staff made our dinner experience very enjoyable. Thank you to the chef and lovely staff. We will definitely come back if we are in Madrid again. Highly recommended :)

title_review: Excellent - an absolute if you visit Madrid
review_preview: ignore the you 'eat in the dark' reviews - and or the ignorant reviews claiming the meat was too rare. Its clear from our visit that both these are either untrue or ignorant claims.Firstly the meat - this is a well run kitchen with...
review_full: ignore the you 'eat in the dark' reviews - and or the ignorant reviews claiming the meat was too rare. Its clear from our visit that both these are either untrue or ignorant claims. Firstly the meat - this is a well run kitchen with good chefs - the meat is excellent and its cooked to chefs liking - usually rare. I would've thought that was a given these days but we personally witnessed a group of dutch people send all their meat back to be, in their own words, deep cooked. So if you're ignorant and like expensive cuts of meat to be completely overcooked then fine but don't claim its a problem of the restaurant,  Secondly re the dark - well it true the place is a little crammed and you will eat partially in the dark - but its dinner and a show. So some sacrifices have to made - we cant expect them to leave all the lights on. Now the food - wow. The pigeon, lamb and beef were all superb. Cooked perfectly and great dishes with interesting sides and sauces - kind of french neo classical cooking. The Iberico starter that we shared was also top notch. Highly recommended

review_preview: Corral de la Morelia is a fine dining experience in it's own right, when you combine it with the Flamenco dance show ... it is quite an experience. The Flamenco dance show lasts one hour and is not a tourist version from Disney, these dancers...
review_full: Corral de la Morelia is a fine dining experience in it's own right, when you combine it with the Flamenco dance show ... it is quite an experience. The Flamenco dance show lasts one hour and is not a tourist version from Disney, these dancers give you the authentic dance with Spanish guitar accompaniment and the venue is compact enough that can feel the dance as well as see and hear it. While tourists (like us) enjoyed the cultural immersion .. most of the patrons were locals and several appeared to know both the wait staff and dancers. Reservations are highly recommended.. however Adam managed to work with the seating manager and we were accommodated when they had a last minute cancellation and it was a lucky break .. the meal, waitstaff, and show are first rate.  It's only a 10 minute walk from the La Latina METRO station on the #5 line .. put it on your Madrid List.

The food was very good and well presented and the service was effecient as well as attentive.  The show costs about 40 Euros on top of the meal so for two the cost is about 180 Euros for show and meal. The club is quite small and low roofed and the tables are quite close together but this adds to the atmosphere. The stage is a raised area in one corner and was easily viewable although there was a couple of supporting colums that may have got in the way for sme tables. The show itself lasted about an hour and a half and we felt was absolutly fantastc. It was dramatic, passonate and the dancers had fabulous technical skills. The level of noise from the guitars, singers and dancers shoes was amazing and made the whole experience the highlight of our trip. Well worth going to and highly recomended.

title_review: Excellent flamenco but seemed to discriminate against single travellers
review_preview: Having recently been to Corral de la Moreria I decided it worthwhile to write a honest review. The flamenco was superb and saved the evening I was fortunate to see  Blanca del Rey who was truly amazing and I would highly recommend people to actively...
review_full: Having recently been to Corral de la Moreria I decided it worthwhile to write a honest review. The flamenco was superb and saved the evening I was fortunate to see Blanca del Rey who was truly amazing and I would highly recommend people to actively seek out her performances, without hesitation. However the main drawback was the food. The first course vegetable Mille Feuille was superb. However for the main course I chose the chicken with a whisper of paella. When I cut into the middle of the chicken it was bright pink and uncooked. As I did not wish salmonella as a souvenir of my visit I had to send it back to the kitchen to be recooked. After I had done this I had to wait a very long time for the main course to be replaced. It would also have been nice to have received an apology from the restaurant that this took place but unfortunately no apologies were forthcoming. Also when the main course was replaced they did not replace the paella accompaniment to the meal. The dessert, rice pudding, was OK but not great. When you are paying a minimum of 43 Euros for the mal the least you could expect is that you are not going to contract food poisoning! The seating arrangements also left something to be desired. Initially I was seated facing a brick wall and with severely restricted sight of the stage. When I complained there seemed to be little to no attempt to reseat me until I insisted that I would leave and that they should reimburse the money that I had paid to see the show. When I started to put on my coat to go they eventually moved me to a position from which I could see the stage. The payment of the bill was fine although they made me wait until the end. To add insult to injury the waitress asked me to add a tip to the bill as "service was not included". It was at this stage that I had to explain to her that I could not possibly tip her as the food was sub-standard, reminded her that I had to send the chicken back to the kitchen and told her that I was fortunate not to have contracted salmonella. So if you want to see superb flamenco (and it was) this venue is excellent. However please be sure to check your food before you eat it as this review comes with a health warning.

review_preview: Touted as the best flamenco show in Madrid, and visited by numerous celebrities, this flamenco show was high on our list of places to visit in Spain last May. We requested reservations for four for a midnight show by internet through the company's on-line reservation...
review_full: Touted as the best flamenco show in Madrid, and visited by numerous celebrities, this flamenco show was high on our list of places to visit in Spain last May. We requested reservations for four for a midnight show by internet through the company's on-line reservation service, 23hours before the performance, and left a credit card number. However we did not receive a confirmation e-mail or phone call, even as late as 5 PM the next day--the day of the show. We made 3 calls to the ticket office that day but were told that if we had not yet received an e-mail confirmation or booking number, there was no reservation. We therefore made other plans for the evening, but were appalled to find the confirmatory e-mail the next day (sent at 5:38 PM, the afternoon of the show.) Sure enough, my credit card was charged for 128 euros ($198.09) for a show we never attended. Multiple phone calls and e-mails to the company requesting a refund were denied. My credit card company disputed the charge but eventually paid the bill, since we did not adhere to the flamenco company's 24 hour cancellation policy (kind of hard to comply when we were not advised of the reservation in a timely manner, plus we would have been thrilled to attend had we been aware of the reservation!) So, the reservation agent's laziness (thank you, Patricia Ledo) was not acknowledged as the real problem in our "miscommunication." And there was no language barrier since the transaction was handled by my daughter who was living in Madrid at the time and very fluent in Spanish. Maybe it's a great show, but don't make last-minute reservations on the Internet, and beware of the siesta mentality!

title_review: Exceptional Tapas in a Modern Setting. Even Better Service.
review_preview: Casa Lolea is in a bright modern space with lots of windows and mirrors reflecting the light. They offer many creative and exceptional tapas, montaditos (tiny, creative, open-faced sandwiches), salads, cheeses and acorn fed ham and pork. We visited three times during our eight days...
review_full: Casa Lolea is in a bright modern space with lots of windows and mirrors reflecting the light. They offer many creative and exceptional tapas, montaditos (tiny, creative, open-faced sandwiches), salads, cheeses and acorn fed ham and pork. We visited three times during our eight days in Madrid (once for dinner, once for breakfast--great options--and once for a quick lunch before we flew home) and tried over a dozen different dishes. All were wonderful and beautifully presented. I particularly liked their montaditos--which they call "Whims for One"--including Guacamole with mushrooms, Confit cod fish, Foie micuit, and very tender sirloin roast beef with Dijon's mustard and roasted onions.They also specialize in sangrias and offer light and refreshing alternatives to the traditional version. The service was the warmest and most friendly we experienced in our three weeks in Spain. The all female staff speak at least some English and English menus are also available. This Madrid branch of its very popular Barcelona namesake has only been open two months, so it is still somewhat undiscovered. Go now before it gets too crowded. (It is a short walk down the street from the highly rated Only You Boutique Hotel.)

review_preview: 4 of us went to this restaurant last Friday for the dinner/ show performance. We were staying at the Ritz, who recommended and booked for us. I assume this is why we got one of the best tables right beside the stage.The venue is...
review_full: 4 of us went to this restaurant last Friday for the dinner/ show performance. We were staying at the Ritz, who recommended and booked for us. I assume this is why we got one of the best tables right beside the stage. The venue is quite small, but was full, and the tables are very close together. I had to go to the loo before I sat down, as I'd never have got out again ! This is certainly mass catering, getting in as many tourists as possible - made me think of school dinners. The menu was confusing. There were 4 set menu options, or a la carte. The minumum charge per person was 35 euros for the show and 42 euros for the cheapest set menu. Having said that, the set menu did include half a bottle of wine and water.  We were put off just looking at the menu, as it seemed the cost could spiral out of control, and simply went for the cheapest option. I had mushroom soup to start, which was very nice. I had chicken for main with dried out paella, of which I ate very little. Dessert was fried custard which I couldnt eat. The wine was fine. The flamenco dancers came on around 21.30 and probably did about 90 minutes. The performers were all excellent and appeared to be very professional, with huge amounts of energy. I doubt anyone would be disappointed with the show, and it was longer than I expected. If you want to see flamenco, I'd go for the later show/drinks option.  Overall we were disappointed, especially as we'd been to La Capilla de la Bolsa the previous evening, which was outstanding (and cheaper).

The dancers were professionally trained and on the table was a biography of their extensive work/instruction elsewhere. They changed costumes and different dancers appeared in different groups during the evening. The quality of...
review_full: Went here for drinks/dessert only in Jan, 2010 - incredible flamenco performance. The dancers were professionally trained and on the table was a biography of their extensive work/instruction elsewhere. They changed costumes and different dancers appeared in different groups during the evening. The quality of the live music, singing and dancing was excellent, and the views were great from anywhere in the restaurant. Despite some other reviews: (a) I did not find the tables too close; (b) I did not find it disruptive for the waiters to serve food / drinks during the show - the waiters were fast and didn't block the view at all, plus convenient if you want to order more drinks. For the quality of entertainment, not a bad price considering the location. Good location with scenic views near the bridge/palace etc. as well. They didn't seem to mind people taking pictures/video either. Would highly recommend this.

We ordered a selection of traditional tapas that included egg and potato tortilla, ham, lamb, potato, and potato dumplings. I wish I could recommend one, but all were excellent ‚Äì you can‚Äôt go wrong with any. What we liked best about the Bombardino Cafe were the ambiance and service ‚Äì informal, good humored, enthusiastically friendly, and like the cuisine authentic. It was an ideal place for a long, relaxed, farewell to people we love and a favorite European city.

title_review: Amazing show, great service but so-so food
review_preview: We went for the show with dinner, booked via a travel agent and everything was prepaid. We booked for the first session and started our dinner at 6:30pm. Being a busy and popular restaurant, the wait staff were exceptionally nice, friendly and attentive, special thanks...
review_full: We went for the show with dinner, booked via a travel agent and everything was prepaid.  We booked for the first session and started our dinner at 6:30pm. Being a busy and popular restaurant, the wait staff were exceptionally nice, friendly and attentive, special thanks to the young gentleman that served our table. We just couldn't praise them highly enough since they had to work in the dark when the show was in progress and maintained an unobtrusive efficiency throughout. The show was undoubtedly great with energetic performers. Guitar playing & singing also formed an important part of the show. Though not as eye-catching as the dances on such a small stage, it was worthy of your appreciation. I have heard the same in the old town of Cuenca, busking, which was really impressive as it perfectly blends into the atmosphere and feels very Spanish. We were seated in the front row, got an unobstructed view of the show, a closer look of the dance steps and a better connection with the performers. However be warned: you may got a stiff neck, and a shower of the performers' sweat, seriously! Our only gripe was the food...disappointing, not bad but certainly not phenomenal...maybe the pre-set menu was not the best that the restaurant could offer or we had expected too much.  Overall it's an unforgettable experience and we didn't regret going there at all. My 2 cents: choose the first session of the show in summer so that you could witness the beauty and awe of the sunset at Plaza de la Armer√≠a after the dinner show.

title_review: Sixth Visit and still leaves me breathless
review_preview: I have been coming here for several years with guests when they visit Madrid. Six times now and it never ceases to impress. I recommend drinks and the show at 9.30. You can have some light food too if you wish (cheese plate ...). If...
review_full: I have been coming here for several years with guests when they visit Madrid. Six times now and it never ceases to impress. I recommend drinks and the show at 9.30. You can have some light food too if you wish (cheese plate ...). If you opt for the dinner and show combined you will not be disappointed, but may find sharing your attention between your meal and the show difficult. The Flamenco is intense and needs your attention! Our waiters, David and Miguel were great - they looked after us extremely well. I shall certainly be back. By the way, some reviews below comment on obstructed views. I have never had a problem. Sure there is a column on the corner of the stage but it does not get in the way.

review_preview: There is a dizzying array of fine quirky bars and restaurants in Madrid but among the best and perhaps my favourite would be Bombardino Caf√© for a multitud of reasons. Variety is the key to this bar which offers a cornucopia of activities and events,...
review_full: There is a dizzying array of fine quirky bars and restaurants in Madrid but among the best and perhaps my favourite would be Bombardino Caf√© for a multitud of reasons. Variety is the key to this bar which offers a cornucopia of activities and events, some regular and some one off: live music (jazz, blues...), micro-theatre, book readings, wine tasting, pub quiz and even Russian Cabaret. To accompany it boasts an extensive wine list including Italian wines, some interesting bottled craft beers, a spano-italian menu and on Fridays a scrumptious set lunch. And above all, friendly service. Can't emphasise that last point enough. Someone else has commented that the bar is like a home from home and I do indeed seem to have adopted it as if it were my own living room.

title_review: Come hungry and prepare for a Madrileno experience
review_preview: We arrived fairly near the close of the lunch opening hours and I think owner was worried we didn't know what we were letting ourselves in for. She said (I think) that the cocina madrileno special was all that was on offer, which was handy...
review_full: We arrived fairly near the close of the lunch opening hours and I think owner was worried we didn't know what we were letting ourselves in for. She said (I think) that the cocina madrileno special was all that was on offer, which was handy as that's what we'd come for Cue a large tureen of thin but tasty chicken soup. When we'd had about half of it, a huge plate of various cooked vegetables appeared, for us to add to the rest of the soup. Once the soup had all gone (we couldn't manage all the veg) a huge platter of meat arrived, with an equally large plate of chips. Really tender beef cheeks (at least that's what i think they were) black pudding, chops, bone marrow and more that I can't now remember, and almost all of it really good. And perfectly acceptable cheap house red Nice atmosphere too

title_review: A little off the beaten track but well worth it (close to the main train station)
review_preview: We are not Madrid experts but we did try to get around and sample the treats of this very international and active city.  In the end, the only place we went twice was Bombardino Cafe, on a side street off the Calle de Santa Isabel...
review_full: We are not Madrid experts but we did try to get around and sample the treats of this very international and active city. In the end, the only place we went twice was Bombardino Cafe, on a side street off the Calle de Santa Isabel not far from the main train station.  One thing we could not help but notice eating out in Madrid; there are the obviously touristy spots, the ones you read about in Lonely Planet, where you might hear some Spanish amongst the English/German/Swedish/French mix, and then there ware the places where the Spanish go. Bombardino is where the Spanish go when they want something modern yet cozy, light meals with some vegetarian options, and a very relaxed and artsy setting. And the best part, you can still find friendly owners who will take care of your wishes, even in English!  We sampled Bombardino (bbd) for both a late breakfast and dinner and were treated to wonderful service, great food, and a throughly charming atmosphere. The two owners were in the restaurant and served up good cheer with warmth and attention and they speak more languages than I will ever manage. There is a clearly Italian flavor to some of the dishes as one of the owners comes from Milan. But this is not a pizza joint, but rather a place where the two cuisines meet and mingle. And where also Spanish diners enjoy drinks, conversations, and yes, a romantic tryst or two! You will rarely go wrong at bbd, something I cannot say about MANY other options in Madrid.

review_preview: We booked Bombardino based on the pictures and reviews which is always a bit of a risk but as soon as we met the guys a couple of days before the party, we knew it was a good choice. We invited 75 guests (mainly British...
review_full: We booked Bombardino based on the pictures and reviews which is always a bit of a risk but as soon as we met the guys a couple of days before the party, we knew it was a good choice.  We invited 75 guests (mainly British but also Spanish, Americans, Italians and others) for drinks and a light dinner. The food was typical Spanish Tapas but they coped with our gluten free/vegetarian/vegan requirements and everyone gave the food the thumbs up. Croquettas, Jamon & Iberian cured meats, Salmorejo & Ravioli. I loved all of it. The drinks were great too including the Sangria. The place was pretty full with our crowd, but could take a few more. There were plenty of staff to serve us and hunt out the Veggies and the atmosphere was great too. Yeah, couldn't really ask for more thank you Emanuele and Jorge Set us up nicely for our big day the next morning! Several of our guests returned for other meals during the wedding week and again with great reivews.

review_preview: I understand this place was the one where the locals used to go to, which is why I chose it.. Now it seemed very touristy to us and expensive for what was offered. We were given a  drink of  our choice (which was quite generous...
review_full: I understand this place was the one where the locals used to go to, which is why I chose it.. Now it seemed very touristy to us and expensive for what was offered. We were given a drink of our choice (which was quite generous in size) and not even a 90 minute show for the admission charge of 88 euros. Thankfully we didn't opt for the dinner. It arrived at many different times during the show and we heard some comments that it was cold but I can't say more than that. The show opened with a group of three men playing guitars but within 15 minutes there was a break in the show til the dancers came on stage. Then three Flamenco dancers looked gorgeous and performed beautifully but before we knew it there was another break. They went back and forth with the guitarist at least two times, more likely three, during the show. We sat looking at each other during the breaks. If the music were continuous, at least. the lapses would not have been that obvious. The performances, however, were definitely fun to watch and the costumes and dances did not disappoint. We would efinitely recommend seeing Flamenco dancers while in Madrid but I wish I had done more homework and maybe found another place to go.

title_review: A ‚ÄúNOT TO BE MISSED‚Äù while in Madrid
review_preview: While visiting Spain seeing a Flamenco show is a must! We had researched and planned on seeing a show in Barcelona but ran out of time and I was very disappointed  (however now I am so happy that I saw this show at this venue...
review_full: While visiting Spain seeing a Flamenco show is a must! We had researched and planned on seeing a show in Barcelona but ran out of time and I was very disappointed (however now I am so happy that I saw this show at this venue instead!) so as we flew into Madrid airport we immediately went to the information desk and the very helpful young man gave us this venue as his first choice for a Flamenco show. I told him I wanted to see a good show. He had been so friendly and helpful with our transportation needs that were absolutely critical to us getting around that we trusted him. Well...like everything that he helped us with - it did not disappoint! We went to Corral de la Moreria the first day in Madrid. We took the metro to the stop Opera. We tried walking around the winding streets from the metro stop and kept getting lost. When we finally found the location (you see beautifully painted lamps outside) we saw an employee letting someone out. He was very helpful. We told him we wanted to see the Flamenco show and he asked if we had tickets. We said no but we wanted to buy them. He personally walked us up to an office and we were able to book them. Both employees were very nice and helpful. They were sold out for that night but we were able to get the tickets for the next day. I would strongly suggest to book online before you leave home and reserve your spot. Our trip would not have been as wonderful without seeing such a fabulous show and you wouldn‚Äôt want to be disappointed if you don‚Äôt get in! It is a smaller intimate venue. There are two shows one at 8:00 and one at 10:00. I would suggest that the day you do the Flamenco show you do the following itinerary: get off of the Metro stop ‚ÄúOpera‚Äù. Walk through Plaza De Oriente then tour the Palacio Real. We then walked down Calle de Bailen past the Jardines de Sabatini to Calle de Ferraz to Parque de la Montana to see the sunset at the Templo de Debod. Afterward we walked back toward the palace. The Corral de la Moreria is past the palace off of Calle de Bailen! It was so easy to get to from there! It is on the side of the palace just past the Jardines de las Vistillas on Calle de la Moreria! We walked since all these places are within walking distance from each other. So now...on with my review of Corral de la Moreria...we entered and were seated right away. We had opted for just the show and a drink. They offer a variety of drinks. The items you can choose from are marked with a Flamenco dancer beside the choices. My husband chose a beer and I chose an Flavored liquor. Delish and given in a generous glass! We decided because of time restraints not to chose the dining option but we would have wanted to choose that option. (David Garcia, Michelin star recipient, was hired in 2016 by Corral de la Moreria so who wouldn‚Äôt want to eat here? I don‚Äôt know if he is still there but no doubt his influence and teaching still is!) I would suggest going early to have your entire meal eaten before the show starts so your attention will be fixed on this fabulous show. I loved how they allow you to take pictures or video first (no flash) then they tell you it is no longer allowed. This allows you to capture the special moment to remember forever by recording so as to enjoy it time and time again since it is beautiful and something you never want to forget but then allows you to totally enjoy the experience with nothing distracting you like seeing the performance through a lens! You totally get immersed in the performance. I have been to NY broadway shows and in my opinion this show‚Äôs performers showed more passion and were so immersed in their performance that it was unlike any performance I‚Äôve ever seen. Throughout the performance you are brought into the show. The guitarists sat down with you at the tables and even the dancers performed down off the stage right beside you before going onto the stage. Truly a performance that draws you into it. These performers were absolutely amazing! The guitar player‚Äôs performances made you feel like they gave a private serenade. With all of the performers you absolutely feel the passionate emotions as each piece is performed. You are given a program with the performers of the night. I absolutely loved all the performers. The Flamenco dancers with their beautiful costumes that I had longed to see, performed greater than all expectations I ever had or anticipated. Jesus, Vanessa, Anabel radiated great passion for their craft by their movements and facial expressions. I was especially pleasantly surprised by the ballerina! Her name is Estela Alonso. She performed the castanets as well as danced. It was something I didn‚Äôt expect in a Flamenco show but WOW! Such grace! This brought this show to another level! Again I say, Really Exceeding expections! I cannot see how anyone would choose another Flamenco show! These performers made their performance a true work of art! The level of talent here was amazing! I cannot praise this venue enough! Don‚Äôt miss out! You will see the famous faces that have been here in the pictures on the wall and on the website! The pamphlet they have says this is the most famous Tablao Flamenco in the world, it won the world‚Äôs best tablao flamenco award (from the most prestigious flamenco festival in Spain), and was selected by the book ‚Äú1000 places to see before you die‚Äù (the NY Times #1 best seller). I totally agree! I will never forget this phenomenal experience. There may be cheaper venues out there but you get what you pay for and the possibility you will be dissappointed and feel the lesser money you spent was not even worth it! This experience at Corral de la Moreria was worth every euro spent! I would gladly spend it again for this once in a lifetime experience! If your gonna do something...do it right with everything you got. They do it perfect!

We got a nice seat close to the stage. The place is tiny and was crowded. But the flamenco and music are absolutely unmissable. The show was really great.  The food was really good especially the the paella and the sangria was also very good. They gave us 1/2 bottle of wine as complementary. Definitely a location that's worth trying, for the dance and for the dishes. If you are in madrid, please reserve one evening for this place.

title_review: "I would fly back to Madrid just to eat here again"
review_preview: Headline was a quote from daughter on our second trip here in 3 days. Would leave 6 or 7 stars if I could. Why? Staff - Fantastic. Friendly, helpful, informative and mostly because they obviously care. We had a friend with who was not sure...
review_full: Headline was a quote from daughter on our second trip here in 3 days. Would leave 6 or 7 stars if I could. Why?  Staff - Fantastic. Friendly, helpful, informative and mostly because they obviously care. We had a friend with who was not sure if she could stay but the staff made room for her any way. Invidious to single out one person as they are all super out but Liere would grace any restaurant as front of house. Also good linguists!!  Restaurant - beautifully presented and decorated.  Sangrias - very very good. 22,000 steps round Madrid in 37 degrees instantly dispelled by Sangria No 3.  Food - Fabulous, so tasty so interesting, Guacamole, Calamari, Cecina all stunning, everything else very good. They have taken 2 Spanish classics (Sangria & Tapas) and re-interpreted them, brave but very successful. Also very well priced!!  There is so much care and effort in this restaurant it absolutely deserves to be an enormous success. Just go and enjoy!!!!! First port of call when we go back to Madrid.

With this in mind yes it can be pricey especially if you go for the dinner but from having compared some of the other flamenco places that sit for dinner, they are pretty similar in pricing. There was also complaints about the audience taking videos and pictures during the performance. The announcements exclusively prohibit this and only allow for the first 5 minutes of the performance. We had no issues. For my friends and I, it was definitely worth it. It was my birthday celebration and we all agreed this would be a great end to a wonderful trip. The food was beyond anything I expected. Truly wonderful experience!

Definitely a location that's worth trying, for the dance and for the dishes.

review_preview: The food was average, but the entertainment was outstanding. The dancers, singers, and guitar players were all wonderful. This was a very exciting evening! Now it‚Äôs a month later, and I‚Äôm still starry-eyed.Check the schedule, and make your reservations so that you start your...
review_full: The food was average, but the entertainment was outstanding. The dancers, singers, and guitar players were all wonderful. This was a very exciting evening! Now it‚Äôs a month later, and I‚Äôm still starry-eyed. Check the schedule, and make your reservations so that you start your meal early enough that you can be more or less finished with your meal when the show starts. Reason: during the show, the restaurant is blacked out. We were served our desserts during the show. I knew from the taste that it was chocolate and very delicious, but I couldn‚Äôt see what it was. Also, try to get a table close to the stage. The show is even more exciting close up. For dinner, we had an interesting salad (on some soggy, thin bread), and poached salmon, which was very fatty. Maybe it was farmed salmon. The service was fine. My only concern was this: A waiter dropped a (clean) wine glass. That can happen anywhere; I don‚Äôt criticize him for that. However, as a result, there were small pieces of broken glass in the area between the tables where people walked. It was quite a while before someone came with a broom to sweep up the glass. I pointed out to that person that there were many pieces of broken glass under another customer‚Äôs chair. The staff person nodded, but she swept only the main walking area, not under the chair. Also, even after the walking area had been swept, bits of broken glass remained.  Their website, in many languages, has a lot of information and many photos..

review_preview: The food was good, the sangria was good, and the space was pretty and well decorated. My husband and I had an enjoyable evening here. Our favorite dish was a mushroom and tender garlic scramble, and the gazpacho was really nice too.However, Casa Lolea...
review_full: The food was good, the sangria was good, and the space was pretty and well decorated. My husband and I had an enjoyable evening here. Our favorite dish was a mushroom and tender garlic scramble, and the gazpacho was really nice too. However, Casa Lolea is EXTREMELY touristy and I wouldn't go back for that reason. The entire place was packed with people who seemed to be from Germany, the Netherlands etc., all speaking English.  We're here for a language immersion in Spanish, so this is the type of place we'd generally avoid because touristy places are the worst for getting "Englished" based on how you look and the fact that you're not a native Spanish speaker. Even if you ask them to speak Spanish with you, they'll still "forget" and go back into English, which is not only super awkward but also frustrating when you've put a huge amount of effort and time into traveling to a country for language immersion. I've found the best/only way to avoid this is to avoid touristy places. I recommend this place if you're looking for good tapas, good sangria and you are NOT in Spain for language tourism.

title_review: The best tourist trap in town
review_preview: We went to El Corral de la Moreria recommended by the concierge from the Palace Hotel where we were staying, something I almost never do since big hotel concierges are famous for sending their guest to tourist traps. So I was pre-disposed against the place...
review_full: We went to El Corral de la Moreria recommended by the concierge from the Palace Hotel where we were staying, something I almost never do since big hotel concierges are famous for sending their guest to tourist traps. So I was pre-disposed against the place since before we arrived but my friends insisted and I obliged. The first impression of a busload full of Easter European tourists waiting outside to get in almost made me turn around. We had a reservation for dinner and the show which starts after dinner is over (around 22:30hrs) and lasts about an hour and a half. We were sat at a table right in front of the stage and had a perfect view, but some areas of the restaurant have partially obstructed views because of columns. Dinner was fairly good though not cheap and the dinner service was attentive and courteous. But let's face it, the star here is the show. Been of Spanish descent and having been to Spain many times I have seen some good ones. The Moreria troop puts on one of the best. By the second number I was clapping to along and by the end I was losing my voice from screaming Bravo! Yes is a tourist trap, but a good one and one you will not soon forget. Absolutely recommend it.

title_review: Sensational - captures the emotional essence of Spain
review_preview: Given the mixed reviews, we were a little wary whether the show would live up to expectations.  In particular my 15 year old son, was fairly hesitant beforehand.   In short, each of us loved the show - definitely the highlight of our trip to Europe......
review_full: Given the mixed reviews, we were a little wary whether the show would live up to expectations. In particular my 15 year old son, was fairly hesitant beforehand.  In short, each of us loved the show - definitely the highlight of our trip to Europe... and has set the tone for a return trip to Spain. The music and emotional spirit in particular were the defining points for us. A small venue with a taverna like feel - we had great seats near the stage and attended the midnight show. We choose not to eat and suggest its best to do so, so you are able to focus on the show. The midnight show finishes around 1:40am, with taxis available at the door. A must do for Madrid.

title_review: Warm welcome, relaxed atmosphere, great food!
review_preview: Went here for a late lunch having been in the area and finding this place highly rated on tripadvisor. I can wholeheartedly agree with the places rating, it is great! The first thing being the staff - both the guys who served us were very...
review_full: Went here for a late lunch having been in the area and finding this place highly rated on tripadvisor. I can wholeheartedly agree with the places rating, it is great! The first thing being the staff - both the guys who served us were very warm and welcoming as well as attentive and efficient- all of which I found lacking in many places I've eaten at in Madrid. They could both speak english and helped us with ordering- there is english on the menu too which helps! The interior is quite funky, eclectic and relaxed. Nothing pretentious or cheesy which is nice.¬† We ordered some raciones including grilled squid with salad, shredded flank steak and boletus risotto with crispy bacon. Everything was delicious, particularly the last two which were interesting and unusual dishes for us. We were too full for dessert but the guys insisted we tried a complementary shot of a local liquor- very welcome and also delicious! If it wasn't lunch time and we hadn't places to go we could have easily spent longer here. The prices were very reasonable and I think the place offers excellent value for money. Overall we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves here and regret not having time to spend longer or to return again during our holiday. I can definitely recommend it and hope to go back next time we visit Madrid!

review_preview: Made it a point to eat in this place as it was relatively close to our hotel, taking into account the overwhelming positive reviews on TripAdvisor. Needless to say, it did not disappoint. From the salad, to the steak (served on a really hot ceramic...
review_full: Made it a point to eat in this place as it was relatively close to our hotel, taking into account the overwhelming positive reviews on TripAdvisor. Needless to say, it did not disappoint.  From the salad, to the steak (served on a really hot ceramic plate that allows the customer to cook the meat to our preference) to the bacalao with cheese on top (first time to try such a thing), the squid, the excellent risotto, and finally, the passion fruit cheesecake, everything we ordered was superb.  As for the service, the servers were very kind and accommodating. We sadly did not get the names of the two gentlemen who served us, but hopefully this review can suffice as a 'thank you' for a memorable first lunch in Madrid.

title_review: great show but rip off menu!!!
review_preview: We went to Madrid in June for our 1st wedding anniversary and wanted to see a flamenco show.  We heard about Corral De La Moreria and was told it was 35euros but when we got there it was 40 euros each just for the show...
review_full: We went to Madrid in June for our 1st wedding anniversary and wanted to see a flamenco show. We heard about Corral De La Moreria and was told it was 35euros but when we got there it was 40 euros each just for the show and the food was supposedly gourmet and very pricey! I orderd lamb and thats pretty much all I got, with the smallest dollop of mash I've ever seen, no veg. The Lamb was very salty and the portion size small, had to get a burger on the way back to hotel as still hungry and it cost me 33 euros! All in all the evening cost us over 150 euros. If your thinking about going, just go to see the show and eat elsewhere - you will save yourselves alot of money and disappointment!!

review_preview: Thank goodness we went to Corral de la Moreria in Madrid, because I was going to wait until we got to Seville to see a flamenco show and if I'd missed this fabulous show in Madrid I would have been very annoyed as Seville (Casa...
review_full: Thank goodness we went to Corral de la Moreria in Madrid, because I was going to wait until we got to Seville to see a flamenco show and if I'd missed this fabulous show in Madrid I would have been very annoyed as Seville (Casa de la Memoria) was such a letdown. Anyhow, we booked for just the show and one drink and had dinner elsewhere, but when we arrived the people seated around us were saying the food was really very good, the show kicked off (!) at 10pm and was so full of energy and everything and more that I had expected from a flamenco performance. The only trouble was a table of men who insisted on talking loudly over the guitars, singing and dancing - it wouldn't have hurt the staff to have asked them to keep quiet as the audience was getting annoyed. Would highly recommend this venue.

title_review: Worth it just for the show
review_preview: The show was fantastic but if you can go see the show without getting the meal that would probably be better. The food was better than I expected, but it was just okay. I had a goat cheese salad, salmon, and the chocolate dessert. All...
review_full: The show was fantastic but if you can go see the show without getting the meal that would probably be better. The food was better than I expected, but it was just okay. I had a goat cheese salad, salmon, and the chocolate dessert. All were satisfying but not over the top. There was a couple who came right before the show that just ordered wine, tapas, and dessert...I was a little jealous of their smarts. Also the stage is very small and if you aren't towards the front you might have to get up and stand along the wall to see the performers' feet as they stomp out their flamenco. The show was good but it was a little irritating when the waiters/waitresses would get up and serve things during the dancing. I would recommend going later in the first session or even going to the later show because then you'd have less interruptions from servers. Overall I'd recommend it if you have not seen flamenco before!

title_review: Bewitching flamenco dance and fine food
review_preview: To watch flamenco dance was one of things on my bucket list, so when I got an opportunity to visit Madrid, visiting Corral De La Moreria was a must.Booking the table for show and dinner was the first step, guaranting ourselves an evening to...
review_full: To watch flamenco dance was one of things on my bucket list, so when I got an opportunity to visit Madrid, visiting Corral De La Moreria was a must. Booking the table for show and dinner was the first step, guaranting ourselves an evening to remember. Stepping into the restaurant is like going into a bygone era, the decor is grand. The chairs and tables though look cramped for space. Drinks came in as we settled, followed by some bread. The first course was lovely and set the tone for the evening Delicious. The main course and the desserts were just yum.  But the highlight of the evening was the dance performance which simply took out breath away. The singers took the tempo high with their vocals and brought life to the evening. And the dancers just captivated our senses. It's a performance that needs to be experienced and no amount of vocabulary will do justice to that experience. Fine Food and excellent dance, made this trip an unforgettable experience.

review_preview: We were in Madrid for 5 nights and we ate here 4 times. Cristian will treat you like family. The atmosphere has a very cool vibe - it is an intimate space - at times they project black and white film clips on the far...
review_full: We were in Madrid for 5 nights and we ate here 4 times. Cristian will treat you like family. The atmosphere has a very cool vibe - it is an intimate space - at times they project black and white film clips on the far wall which adds to the charm. The service is also very good. The presentation of the food is beautiful and creative. I highly recommend the croquetas - they are like a drug they are so good. The Tromp l'oeil Parmesan risotto with truffle oil is also sensational. The tuna tataki is out of this world - we are raving about it still. The patatas bravas were excellent. The hummus is also good, The octopus tentacle was quite good it has a smoky (think hickory) flavor that may not appeal to all palates. The cod was gigantic and moist and flavorful and enough to feed two. Very generous portion. The chicken tapas was also excellent. You will not regret the visit. The sangria was also good.

title_review: Stopped for a rest - left with a smile
review_preview: During a self-guided walking tour of Madrid, we stopped at La Mi Venta for a beverage hoping to have a small rest and an energy boost to continue our afternoon.  What we did not expect was an extremely friendly restaurant/bar with some of the nicest...
review_full: During a self-guided walking tour of Madrid, we stopped at La Mi Venta for a beverage hoping to have a small rest and an energy boost to continue our afternoon.  What we did not expect was an extremely friendly restaurant/bar with some of the nicest Spaniards we met in 2+ weeks of traveling who took us under their watch and for one hour truly made us feel welcome. And they have the best jamon/ham carver around! All I can say is "Just go" - make a dinner reservation if you can't stop by for a small break in your sightseeing itinerary - the downstairs dining room is amazing! Thank you to Ivan and the staff - I can't tell you how much we appreciated the warm welcome and hospitality.

review_preview: We were brought here after visiting Rosi la Loca initially after being told there were no tables, and were taken to the front of the queue in order to get a table. We had been promised a 20% discount and a seat immediately by the...
review_full: We were brought here after visiting Rosi la Loca initially after being told there were no tables, and were taken to the front of the queue in order to get a table. We had been promised a 20% discount and a seat immediately by the man who walked us over. We then waited 15 minutes for our table but eventually were sat. The servers were lovely, but obviously overrun, however they did their best to attend to our every need. Our server explained the menu very well to us and gave us pointers as to what to have, as it was a little confusing and not laid out like a conventional menu. The sangria pitcher we had was gorgeous, it had gin in it which was a nice, modern twist on a classic. The bao buns we had as a starter were exquisite, however, it went rapidly downhill with the main course paella. It was nicely cooked, or so we thought until we returned home and spent the night alternating between toilet and bed. And yes, we did clean the prawns out. To add insult to injury, we didn't receive our promised 20% discount on the meal. A real shame that our night there had to end like that as everything else was great!

review_preview: We visited on Monday evening (04/05/2014) as we wanted a less casual dinner for our last night in Madrid. We sat outside which was lovely despite the busy road behind us. The service was very efficient and friendly and you got the sense that nothing...
review_full: We visited on Monday evening (04/05/2014) as we wanted a less casual dinner for our last night in Madrid. We sat outside which was lovely despite the busy road behind us. The service was very efficient and friendly and you got the sense that nothing was too much for them. For food we ordered calamari to share and then the Hake and for dessert the chocolate mousse (despite the waiter's attempt to get us to try the passionfruit soup!). All of the food was delicious, the fish was cooked particularly well and served with some really nice vegetables. We also had some cocktails (mojitos which were very nice and the house cocktail which was lovely as long as you like strong gin cocktails!). It was pricier than the other places we had eaten at in Madrid but was definitely more of a fine dining experience which is what we were looking for. The only thing that left a slightly sour taste in the mouth was that bread and oil was brought to the table but they charged for it - there was no mention of a charge and they did not ask if we would like the bread so we assumed it was complimentary as it had been everywhere else we had eaten. Otherwise a great evening though!

title_review: Cheerful service, good food, try it
review_preview: This is the best restaurant we have so far found in Madrid during a few short visits.  Staff are helpful and welcoming, and David who seems to be in charge downstairs is an exceptionally cheerful and talkative counsellor on everything from the quality of the...
review_full: This is the best restaurant we have so far found in Madrid during a few short visits. Staff are helpful and welcoming, and David who seems to be in charge downstairs is an exceptionally cheerful and talkative counsellor on everything from the quality of the olive oil (extremely good) to the starters the meat and the wine. This is a meat eaters restaurant, with lots of very good food. Choose your own tapas - the little grilled peppers were delicious, also try the croquetas caseras - and don't go for the house tapas selection, which is rather ordinary.,.Huge T bone steak shared between two was excellent, and an entrecote and a dish of squid in onion sauce both got the thumbs up. The pork Presa Iberica was however dry, overcooked and inedible - David became less cheerful on this and informed us repeatedly it was their most expensive meat (which just made it worse, since he wasn't offering any replacement or price reduction). Deserts were good - mine was a lemon pie which was excellent. Quite expensive but fair for the food quality overall (pity they didn't handle the one bad dish a bit better). Our party of 5 had a really good evening here.

review_preview: It has never been so difficult to write a review of a restaurant. I have very divided opinions. Overall, the restaurant has good points and some a little less good sides.  Reading the reviews of other people and other restaurants I impose the conclusion that...
review_full: It has never been so difficult to write a review of a restaurant. I have very divided opinions. Overall, the restaurant has good points and some a little less good sides. Reading the reviews of other people and other restaurants I impose the conclusion that obviously a lot of it depends on which part of the world you come from. Americans are more enthusiastic about Europe, while Europeans are more enthusiastic about America. We chose La Mi Venta restaurant reading other reviews on Trip Advisor. We made reservation via the Internet and there was no problem. Welcome to the restaurant was at a high level and professional and very friendly. As we had booked dinner for 20:00 the restaurant was nearly empty. We asked the waiter to recommend us what to eat and drink. On his recommendation, we took the T-bone steak, green peppers, potatoes, salad and wine and as a starter Jamon. Now ..... those doubts from the beginning of the text. The ambience of the restaurant ...... OK, but nothing special. In my country there are lots of such restaurants and not something that impressed me, and certainly not left a WOW effect. Nice, clean, neat, comfortable, but nothing special. Food ...... well it is difficult to say. In short, I ate better, but I was eating worse. Jamon was maybe a little too greasy. I say maybe. For the taste of my wife it was. T-bone, in my opinion, a bit too greasy, but OK. Potatoes good, good salad, good wine. All in all, good and average, but nothing really special. Maybe we chose the wrong, maybe We have not been lucky. But for the end I would like to complimented restaurant staff who were very friendly on arrival and on departure and dedicated us their full attention.  Would I recommend La Me Venta to others? I would  Would I come again? Yes and I will. PS. When you are booking over the internet, you have to enter the country of origin, but the choice is really weird

title_review: Sorry, may have been just an off day but average.
review_preview: Based on the other excellent reviews, I was really looking forward to my meal at La Mi Venta, which was just a short walk from my hotel.It was not particularly busy when I arrived as it was quite early and I choose an outside...
review_full: Based on the other excellent reviews, I was really looking forward to my meal at La Mi Venta, which was just a short walk from my hotel. It was not particularly busy when I arrived as it was quite early and I choose an outside table, which had a partial view of the lovely Palace. I had already looked at the menu on the internet and had picked out the Entrecote steak. Perhaps it was just an off day, but unfortunately the meat was a bit on the chewy side and although asking for rare, it was also cooked closer to medium rare - this was fine though. The accompanying potatoes with green peppers was very nice, but the main part of the meal as mentioned was just average compared to many other restaurants I have visited charging similar rates (about 20 Euros). The service was attentive and I could not fault that aspect. This may be Spanish related, but the annoying thing was that some bread and olive oil had been brought to my table when I arrived. I assumed that this was complementary, as it is still at many restaurants, but upon checking the bill I was charged for this without being asked if I wanted it. I did not query this at is was just less than 2 Euros and I had had a long day and did not want to get into an argument. If there are extras, then a restaurant should really make this clear if they are to be charged though. I would like to give it a second chance if I returned, but with so many other good restaurants to choose from, I will likely not be returning.

review_full: Really enjoyed our visit here and especially the enthusiasm, honesty and knowledge of our waiter David.  The restaurant itself is situated downstairs in a cellar and this adds to the old world charm of the place. You really do get a sense that you are somewhere different.  The wine we were recommended was excellent and very good value. The food was good value too - although I think we might have chosen slightly better.  We decided on a selection of tapas some of which were very good - Iberico ham and Padron peppers and some which were not so good - the snails and the chorizo, which were gritty and very fatty respectfully.  Would be perfectly happy to return and give it another go though.

As some reviewers point out, the place can get busy during typical spanish dinner time (from 9pm to 11pm) so it's a good idea to make a reservation first. The service was absolutely excelent. The waiter talked about what makes that place different, brought us some olive oil samples, explained everything we wanted from the menun and even showed raw meat so we could check how soft it was even before being cooked. They have an english menu, if preferred. Food was good, tapas and pinchos (for 2 or 3) are worth the price. Don't miss their "Presa Iberica" as main course, very different.

review_preview: La Mi Venta is a real find, and worth a visit. It is in a quieter neighborhood of the city, and has some outdoor seating available. The interior is charming-not elegant, but lots of charm and character. There are two seating areas in the lower...
review_full: La Mi Venta is a real find, and worth a visit. It is in a quieter neighborhood of the city, and has some outdoor seating available. The interior is charming-not elegant, but lots of charm and character. There are two seating areas in the lower level, both nice, but ask for the one on the right as it has a bit more enticing decor. The food was excellent, and reasonably priced. They specialize in pork dishes, which they do very well. We had excellent service. Special kudos to our waiter, Aitor, who was friendly, efficient, and very helpful. When we had trouble picking a wine, he gave us samples to try. This place is a very good value. Not at all formal.

Amazing produce at very reasonable prices in a lovely setting brought by people with passion, dedication, eye for detail and clearly a lot of love for their job. David has taken care of us like we were at his house. The olive oil, the wine, the food, .. everything is handled with so much love and detail. It was a true inspiration to see him work and it made me happy because unfortunately passionate people like him are rare to find in the industry.  I'm already looking forward to the next time we visit my partners parents in Spain, so we can visit this restaurant again. No need to go anywhere else, it just cant get any better.  Thank you very much for a truly wonderful night.

From the olive oil over the croquettas and chorizo from hell to the delightful T bones and very tasty hake, all six of us had a wonderful gastronomic evening. The postres, the grappa and a few pictures in the beautiful dining room downstairs concluded a charming evening and family dinner in Madrid. Thank you David and other kind people at Mi Venta. This is a place we really recommend to all Madrid travelers. Around the corner of the Palazio Real and very close to the Gran Via. Last point: you get great value for your money. Not expensive at all.

review_preview: I arranged for a small group dinner at La Mi Venta and Ivan (a member of the family that owns the restaurant) could not have been nicer or more cooperative and responsive in arranging for the dinner or during the dinner itself. The food and...
review_full: I arranged for a small group dinner at La Mi Venta and Ivan (a member of the family that owns the restaurant) could not have been nicer or more cooperative and responsive in arranging for the dinner or during the dinner itself. The food and service (including Ivan, the bartender and the waiter)were superb, as was the ambiance. Upstairs there is casual dining at the bar and a few tables; downstairs there are two dining rooms; and out front there are a few tables. The family is responsible for importing a special type of jambon from another region in Spain, which is not to be missed. Indeed, all of the courses were tremendous. This is a small restaurant near the Palace, the Senate building, and other popular sites so I would make reservations in advance, if possible. I cannot say enough good things about this place so I will end by simply recommending that if you want to have an excellent meal at an authentic Spanish restaurant that is staffed by very nice and professional people, make plans to go here.

title_review: One of the Best meals I've ever had and the owner is AMAZING
review_preview: we found this place from trip advisor and went for dinner around 8:30-9ish. We got a table outside, the place is very small but so perfect. The waiters were super attentive and never let your glasses go empty. The food was hands down incredible, i...
review_full: we found this place from trip advisor and went for dinner around 8:30-9ish. We got a table outside, the place is very small but so perfect. The waiters were super attentive and never let your glasses go empty. The food was hands down incredible, i still crave it ALL THE TIME. we got the spanish omellette which was so light and fluffy and the potatoes were cooked to perfection. we had tried a lot of omelets other places and those barely touched this one. The iberica Jamon plate, i recommend getting the largest plate because you will want more, was probably one of the best things I've put in my mouth. i became a Iberica Jamon addict in Spain and tried it at every restaurant we went to, but La Mi Venta's was hands down the best no competition. We also got the bread with tomato which you get everywhere in spain, but this place still managed to be better then everyone else for such a simple thing. the tomato's were so fresh and they gave you such a generous serving of the tomato spread unlike everywhere else where they do such an incredibly thin thin thin layer. The olive oil they give you to start off with your bread is amazing, the best quality olive oil you can find! The owner of this restaurant was one of the most amazing guy's i have ever met. This man has a real passion for food and truly cooks from his heart and cares about quality, he's not in this for the money he's in it for the love of the food and you can truly see that. after the meal you get a complimentary shot that differs in kind all the time. The prices are reasonable for the quality that you are getting, if you want a dirt cheap price then your going to get dirt cheap quality food. I'm a poor college student but felt that this restaurant was worth going back to every night since the day we found it because it was just beyond anything else in the area.

title_review: Highlight of our time in Madrid!!!
review_preview: A lingering late lunch of burrata injected with pesto and Cajon appetizers, with a shared paella main course were perfectly prepared and served in every way.  Waiter Santiago and host Cristian were very attentive and helpful in explaining many inventive menu items to Spanish language...
review_full: A lingering late lunch of burrata injected with pesto and Cajon appetizers, with a shared paella main course were perfectly prepared and served in every way. Waiter Santiago and host Cristian were very attentive and helpful in explaining many inventive menu items to Spanish language challenged travellers such as us. The Cajon de Esto no es Tomato (translated "This is not a tomato!") turns out to be a tomato shaped vegetable tortilla, lightly fried and paired with a tasty dipping sauce that changes daily. The day we were there it was an aioli sauce that was perfecto. Other days it might be a truffle pate or something else delicious. Cristian saw us nibbling around the sauce and explained to us that "without dipping the dish makes no sense!" He was absolutely right!  Wonderful meal. Wonderful time.  Thank you Santiago! Thank you Cristian!

review_full: My wife, two teen boys, and I ate there on the evening of King Felipe's coronation. Our meal, served downstairs in the "cave" (appears to be a former brick n mortar smokehouse), was unbelievable. We had the hake and fried cheese gazpacho as appetizers; hake cheek, goat shank, and escargot as entr√©es; and apple strudel, ice cream soup, and tangerine sorbet for dessert. David even supplied the adults with a shot of cream grappa post dessert. It was a great first dinner for our three nights in Madrid. Yes, it was a bit pricey...but it was well worth it.

title_review: Ivan is great as is the chorizo from hell!
review_preview: My husband booked this restaurant for a large group meal for his international students from The States.  What a fabulous experience!  Ivan spoke English and helped coordinate the menu by email to accommodate our budget.   The downstairs Cave is so unique with its curved brick...
review_full: My husband booked this restaurant for a large group meal for his international students from The States. What a fabulous experience! Ivan spoke English and helped coordinate the menu by email to accommodate our budget. The downstairs Cave is so unique with its curved brick walls and hooks and the large private room is high ceilinged and an enjoyable setting for a meal. The AC was also perfect! It is HOT in madrid . . . not that that is a bad thing! The wait staff was professional and approachable . . . Those two don't always go together. We enjoyed the many courses. The ham fed from the acorn eating pigs-- a must. The salad was delicious with asparagus and many different fresh lettuce varieties. The coal grilled steak was divine. The vegetable dishes perfect as well. And there was not a fried egg any where. We were getting a little sick of the fried egg plopped on French fries or salad! The dessert platters were a lovely variety of apple and cherry pie, cheesecake souffl√© ice cream, lemon meringue and fabulous chocolates to top it off. We were lucky we were allowed down the street to get to the restaurant as the police where blocking off the street as a result of the prince's coronation the next day, June 19, 2014. A fantastic night. We loved it, the students did too. Muchos gracias to Ivan!

review_preview: I booked this restaurant online based on good reviews on trip advisor. I wanted some where special to take my partner for his 40th Birthday. Seeing as my partner is South African, the meat selection had to be good. I had a Spanish colleague call...
review_full: I booked this restaurant online based on good reviews on trip advisor. I wanted some where special to take my partner for his 40th Birthday. Seeing as my partner is South African, the meat selection had to be good. I had a Spanish colleague call the restaurant to explain it was a special occasion and he requested that we were well taken care of. Restaurante La Mi Venta did not disappoint at all, from start to finish the food and the service was exceptional. All the staff were very welcoming and friendly and really wanted to make sure we had the best evening. review_preview: We went there on a "tip" from a co-worker and frankly just don't get this place. The waiter was one of the worst we have ever come across while living here in Madrid. When asked what is the difference between the two sets of cocktails...
review_full: We went there on a "tip" from a co-worker and frankly just don't get this place. The waiter was one of the worst we have ever come across while living here in Madrid. When asked what is the difference between the two sets of cocktails (in Spanish), we literally got the answer that these "are called this and these ones are named that..." Wha?  We ordered two drinks which actually tasted fine but one came with a mini sombrero with a straw poking through it. It was serious shades of Chevy's, but I digress. My partner removed the hat and we can't figure out how they clean these things between drinks. (Don't answer...we know they don't!) Decor- they need to choose one. There is a lot going on in here and all the "themes" are competing with each other. Expensive food for what it was. A 4 euro mini bao...no thanks. The sardines "our way" are cool-ish. They came like little paninis hung on a "clothes line" with a fuming pot of dry ice underneath. The confit cod was ok-ish as well but it took us half the dish to get into it. And, when I say get into it- that means we ended up saying "hmmm, not as bad as I initially thought it would be".   Ideas are there but there needs to be better execution for what they are charging.

review_preview: We couldn't leave Madrid without visiting a Tablao. I came to Spain a couple of times before but never had the chance to attend a Flamenco Show. I read few reviews and decided to visit el Corral de la Moreria, had more expectations about the...
review_full: We couldn't leave Madrid without visiting a Tablao. I came to Spain a couple of times before but never had the chance to attend a Flamenco Show. I read few reviews and decided to visit el Corral de la Moreria, had more expectations about the show than the food. I hardly know about flamenco, can say dancers and singers look absolutely passionate about what they were doing, I don't know if flamenco stages are always that small, or if the combination between women and men is the right one, but I'm extremely into fine dining and everything about food, and I have to say dinner was amazing. My wife had the Lamb and I had a fillet of Lubina as mains, we had the Ox carpaccio and the grilled tomato filled with Squid (chipirones) over black risotto (made with Squid's ink). Dessert was to die for.  Service was very agile and courteous. Tables are close to each other, but is not uncomfortable, it is better if you find a table next to the stage.

review_preview: Our trip to Spain would not have been complete without a trip to watch Flamenco. While the best place to watch Flamenco is probably in Seville and we did visit it, the timing did not work for us so we decided to do it in...
review_full: Our trip to Spain would not have been complete without a trip to watch Flamenco. While the best place to watch Flamenco is probably in Seville and we did visit it, the timing did not work for us so we decided to do it in Madrid. This was truly the highlight of our trip to Spain. When we were researching this place, we realized that this place is booked sometimes months in advance.We decided to take our chances because we were booking in low season and pretty much got the last few seats. There are three available choices and we chose to go for the choice in the middle ( approx $ 125 per person ) which included dinner as well as the show. We were apprehensive about dinner, but that turned out to be the most enjoyable and delicious meal we had in Spain. The seating is cramped with barely any elbow room, but the service was amazing. Our server was amazing and took all our orders when we sat down and even reserved our desserts for us. If you have a sweet tooth like me, get the dessert sampler. It was amazing! The main course was veal and the starters included tiger shrimp. This included a glass of wine and if you ask they will swap the wine for Sangria, like they did for me. We had primarily gone there for the flamenco so we weren't expecting to be fed this well.  Now about the dance...there was live music and 5 flamenco dancers performing the dance. We were told in Seville that Flamenco dancing took inspiration from Indian clasical dance and sure enough the footwork of Flamenco reminded me of the classical dance form of Katthak. The dancers were extremely graceful and the performance was spell binding. It started after dinner got over at about 10 pm and continue for almost an hour and half. If you are in Madrid and would like a cultural experience, I would say this is a must do. We visited the palace and the Prado too, but this is surely the experience I will remember for ever. The staff at this place is great. Make sure you book in advance if you go during tourist season!!

review_preview: I've seen two shows, both different; one with the dinner crowd which started at 22.00, even though we took the show only option. Diners are asked to get there earlier so that food service etc doesn't  interfere too much with the non stop performance. Guitarist,...
review_full: I've seen two shows, both different; one with the dinner crowd which started at 22.00, even though we took the show only option. Diners are asked to get there earlier so that food service etc doesn't interfere too much with the non stop performance. Guitarist, singers and particularly the dancers don't hold back on the level of energy and enthusiasm they throw into their art. Having thoroughly enjoyed this first opportunity to experience flamenco in Madrid, we returned several days later and attended the midnight show which seemed a little more intimate with quite a bit more rapport between performers and audience, there more for the show than the food (which all seemed to be at a very reasonable price in addition to the admission cost to the show that everyone pays. We had thought the food might have been at a rip off but not so). The whole package was professional, exhilirating and one thing you must do when in Madrid. Online booking on their site was trouble free and Corral de la Moreria is easy to find.

review_preview: We booked this show/dinner on the Internet and the communication was prompt and efficient.We opted for the a la carte dinner as one of our party has food allergies. There was a minimum priceof 43 euros, which matched the set menu price. The...
review_full: We booked this show/dinner on the Internet and the communication was prompt and efficient. We opted for the a la carte dinner as one of our party has food allergies. There was a minimum price of 43 euros, which matched the set menu price. The tables were a bit cramped and close together. We had a very relaxed waitress who spoke good English, and we enjoyed all the food. The service was not rushed and we were ready for the show which started promptly at 22.00. What a show! Brilliant dancers, great guitarists and singers. It was mesmerising! The colors and sounds stay in your mind for a long time. We did not experience any breaks in the show apart from costume changes, and we could not fault it. It is supposed to be the best flamenco experience in Madrid and certainly lived up to its reputation. Don't hesitate to go if you like flamenco. The show cost is 40 euros.
