title_review: Wow - what a treat, a must experience
review_preview: I've experienced 4 "Flamenco's" in Spain; Barcelona, Sevilla & Madrid. However, this time was my first time I enjoyed an understood the program. Two guitarists, 4 singers & 3 dancers. 1st program, each singer's melody about their dying mother, death and burial; mixed with the...
review_full: I've experienced 4 "Flamenco's" in Spain; Barcelona, Sevilla & Madrid. However, this time was my first time I enjoyed an understood the program. Two guitarists, 4 singers & 3 dancers.  1st program, each singer's melody about their dying mother, death and burial; mixed with the dancer's emotional performance.  2nd program, singers request for a one night stand since she knows that for them love is only good for one night.  3rd program, artistic and full of technique.  A must see performance, the best. The included drink is from a large selection of reputable brands; BACARDI, Dewars, Jack Daniels Red Label, Absolute, Stoli, 43, Tanquery, and so fourth. Make time to see this performance; the price is worth the time.

review_preview: My parents were coming to Madrid for the weekend and I asked some locals about the best flamenco experience in town. I therefore had great expectations about this place. Unfortunately, we had an extremely unpleasant (and very expensive!) experience.First of all: the table. Right...
review_full: My parents were coming to Madrid for the weekend and I asked some locals about the best flamenco experience in town. I therefore had great expectations about this place. Unfortunately, we had an extremely unpleasant (and very expensive!) experience. First of all: the table. Right at the bottom of the room, on the side of the stage, next to the kitchen. Poor and reduced view of the show, constant noise from the kitchen, the waiters going back and forth durng the show and disturbing the view. And we payed exactly the same as the people sitting in the front row! The dinner: all the glasses on the table were dirty, so we asked to replace them. The food is good, but it is extremely overpriced. Plus, the VAT isn't comprised in the prices showed on the menu, which is illegal in Spain. Being the VAT at 21%, the surprise on the bill is big. We payed more than 40‚Ç¨ per person for a one-course meal, more than then double of a normal restaurant in Madrid. In addition, portions are very limited. Maybe the people having a very expensive drink in the front row had a better experience, but I will surely never EVER go back to El Corral de la Moreria. Worst dinner experience in over 6 months in Madrid. Do not come here for dinner, do not come here for the flamenco, do not come here for drinks. Avoid this place and give your money a better value.

review_preview: I found this great place on trip advisor when another we planned to go to was closed. It was so nice and had incredible service. I went for lunch with a girlfriend and had such a great time! I told my family about it and...
review_full: I found this great place on trip advisor when another we planned to go to was closed. It was so nice and had incredible service. I went for lunch with a girlfriend and had such a great time! I told my family about it and we went for dinner as well. The food is truly delicious and they have a very good wine list. Some of our favorites were the Bacalao with mushrooms, the tuna tartar, and the filet de vaca. Everything on the menu is amazing that I have tried so far. I also really liked the staff, and they were all very kind and friendly and they genuinely seemed to believe in the restaurant and the mission to give great service and provide excellent food in a beautiful setting. I especially liked Guillermo, my server at lunch and he made an incredible wine recommendation. I also really liked Henry, and he had a very positive attitude and was constantly smiling. At dinner, our server was Nelson, and he seemed so happy and patient with us. The staff make this great place incredible. Also, most of the staff speak English, which is a huge plus if you don't speak Spanish. review_full: The Corral de la Moreria is well known for its flamenco show, but we decided to go for the evening dinner alone. We spent a wonderful evening in the exclusive restaurant beside the tablao with seating for just eight people, and enjoyed the peace and quiet of dining without straining to hear across the table, with the luxury of live music in the background. The tasting menu was a combination of sophistication and simplicity. Each dish was light, beautifully presented, and thoughtfully paired with the right sherry by the sommelier. An incredible meeting of Basque cuisine with Andalusian wines. We will be back.

title_review: Undeniably the best New Year‚Äôs Eve evening ever!
review_preview: Best New Year‚Äôs Eve ever! We had an absolute blast at this restaurant! I cannot say enough about what a great time our group had!My boyfriend and I debated for several months about going here on New Year‚Äôs Eve with his goddaughter on our...
review_full: Best New Year‚Äôs Eve ever! We had an absolute blast at this restaurant! I cannot say enough about what a great time our group had! My boyfriend and I debated for several months about going here on New Year‚Äôs Eve with his goddaughter on our trip to Spain because it was rather pricy‚Ä¶ but it was a phenomenal night and I highly recommend it! (His goddaughter even said it was ‚Äúthe best night of her life‚Äù. This was a graduation gift, so she was old enough to appreciate the food and entertainment. I‚Äôm not sure if it would have been as good had she been younger.) For about $300 per person: *7:30pm-1:30am *6 dinner courses *Dessert *Champagne, 2 white wines, 1 red wine, and 1 sherry (all perfectly paired with the food and refills included) *Water (worth mentioning, because we needed it with as much alcohol that was available) *‚ÄúGrapes of Luck‚Äù at midnight *Bag of fun party favors, hats, etc. *Full night of entertainment ‚Äì guitars, singers, and flamenco dancers STAFF ‚Äì Our waiter, Sergio, was incredibly attentive and charming. He kept our waters and wines full all night and even brought us an extra dessert because he saw that we enjoyed it so much. He also found time to get us onstage so we could get a group picture. FOOD ‚Äì Absolutely gourmet! The courses included: 1. "Royal de Foie Gras‚Äù with Sliced Black Truffles 2. Winter Orchard (sort of an interesting veggie dish) 3. Free Range Egg Yolk with Pheasant Consomm√© and Caviar 4. Grilled Lobster with Thyme Confit Potatoes and Creamy Lobster Coral Soup 5. Roasted Sea Bass, Stewed Spring Onion and Citrus Vinaigrette with Sanlucar Manzanilla Sherry 6. Roasted Rack of Lamb on a Chestnut and Duck Gizzard Ragout with Fresh Shoots 7. Caramelized French Toast in Fresh Milk and Vanilla Bourbon with Guanaja Cocoa Ice Cream Everything was delicious and full of interesting flavors. Each course was distinct and I couldn‚Äôt believe how complex the sauces were. Exceptional! ENTERTAINMENT ‚Äì We felt like we were at a party with all friends. The setting at this restaurant is incredibly intimate. All of the performers were absolutely extraordinary! We went to another flamenco show in Seville earlier in the week, but this group somehow felt much more passionate. (And they looked like they were really enjoying the evening too!) TRANSPORTATION ‚Äì The restaurant contacted us before the date and arranged to have us shuttled home so we didn‚Äôt have to walk back to our hotel inebriated after a long, fun, and busy evening. Overall, I would still consider the evening fairly expensive, but the value came through the six hours of gourmet food, stellar entertainment, considerate staff, provided transportation, and open bar. We felt that an a la carte experience with the same factors could have easily been more expensive per person. So once we were committed to the cost, it was great to have a no-stress, ‚Äúeverything included‚Äù New Year‚Äôs Eve evening. Undeniably the best New Year‚Äôs Eve ever! Small note: The other reviews I‚Äôve read are correct - there is a pole that sometimes hinders the view of the stage. If the stage is a diamond shape, it is in the bottom corner. The performers moved so often that it didn‚Äôt really bother us.

title_review: Flamenco Thumbs Up, Gastronomic Experience Thumbs Down
review_preview: This is a tough review since we really enjoyed the entertainment (4 stars) and thought the food was disappointing (2 stars).  If you have dinner before the show at the restaurant you will get better seating, but we are not sure if its worth it....
review_full: This is a tough review since we really enjoyed the entertainment (4 stars) and thought the food was disappointing (2 stars). If you have dinner before the show at the restaurant you will get better seating, but we are not sure if its worth it. Dinner with wine cost us 130 Euros for 2 people. The show cost us around $107 (not Euros). I would stay away from the Paella. While people think its traditional Spanish fare, its actually quite touristy in its preparation. Go for a fish dish instead as they seemed to be much nicer. Dessert was the best part fo the meal, get the 5 chocolate one if you dare. Service overall was very good and they do speak many languages, including English and German. Since if you go there you are going for the show ASK TO BE SEATED AS FAR AWAY FROM THE BAR AS POSSIBLE. The staff is very noisy and it distracts from the show. There are also a couple of beams that get iin the way, but that is a minor distraction, but ask for the unobstructed view. We got there at 7:30 for the 8:00 show and we were the first ones in line. This would be fun for children over age 7 or so since there is singing and guitar playing plus the dancing, s younger children might get bored. I must note we did not see children there, however our children would have enjoyed it. After the show, walk down the street to your left to get a taxi before everyone else figures out there are no taxi's waiting outside the restaurant.

review_preview: We visited the Corral primarily to experience the flamenco singing and dancing. The first show was available if we also had dinner, and since we're traveling with our 9-year old daughter, the 11:30 p.m. was too late. First, the food. My wife and I chose...
review_full: We visited the Corral primarily to experience the flamenco singing and dancing. The first show was available if we also had dinner, and since we're traveling with our 9-year old daughter, the 11:30 p.m. was too late.  First, the food. My wife and I chose one of the prix fixe menus. The first course of huge prawns was all right, following by the paella that also had prawns, which was too many prawns in one meal. Perhaps I don't know what authentic Spanish paella should taste like, but this is my second bad paella experience in one week. It was too salty. The chocolate dessert was the best part of the meal. We ordered the tortilla de patatas for our daughter, which usually never disappoints. Unfortunately, this recipe oddly used onions, which is common in American recipes but not Spanish, according to my wife who lived in Madrid for a year. So our daughter, who doesn't like onions made it through a couple of small pieces. Our waiter took it away and brought back an omelette and fries‚Äì‚Äìsuccess. Why don't they have some kids options? The Corral has the best flamenco music and dance show in Madrid, so no problem there. The three guitarists and three male singers came out first. The percussion of the singers' feet and handclaps was rhythmic and powerful all night. Such a pleasure to be in an acoustic atmosphere with no amplification! The three lady dancers were fabulous, and the solo male and female featured dancers were simply out of this world.  The show has three sections separated by two solo guitar features. This is the point where I wanted to smack some people around, since everyone started talking as it were an intermission with no music. The performers will give you a better performance if they think you are actually listening, plus it's rude to those who want to hear it clearly without your chatter. Eventually most people caught on and quit talking. Remember, he's not a jukebox, he's a human being. One other issue: there is a big sign in the foyer that instructs everyone to avoid flash photography for the safety of the dancers on a three-foot stage. It's also annoying to everyone around you to be in the middle of a strobo/lightning storm. Care to guess how many flashes went off in the course of an hour and a half?  So in summary: the flamenco music and dance is great. Food is probably good, depending on what you order (avoid the paella). Many of your fellow tourists from around the globe may be unfamiliar with live performance decorum, hence the talking and the flashing during the show. If you don't have kids with you, eat dinner somewhere else and hit the 11:30 p.m. show.

review_full: On my recent trip to Madrid, my friend and I were craving something slightly more elevated from the typical fare we were getting from the tapas joints in the Plaza Mayor area where we were staying. Thanks to Yelp, we stumbled upon Taberna el Sur and its safe to say this will be a staple of any future trips. While the restaurant specializes in tradition Spanish tapas, it does so with a twist and approachable sophistication. For reference, we ordered ‚Äúcroquetas de champignons‚Äù, ‚Äúgambones‚Äù and ‚Äúpatatas bravas‚Äù, along with several cocktails and glasses of wine. The quality of the food, flavor, freshness, presentation exceeded our expectations. It also is an incredible value for the amount charged.  Apart from the food, the staff was incredibly charming, friendly, hospitable and knowledgeable about the area. We spent a while there speaking with our servers, in particular Frank, who we also saw conversing with guests in their native languages, making the experience all the more welcoming.

title_review: Perfect evening, perfect moment, and a perfect place for it.
review_preview: Finely positioned and maintained, Mas Al Sur is one of the prime restaurants of Madrid. Located in the Calle Santa Isabel 35 St, just north of Reina Sofia, this wonderful and crowded restaurant provides a cheerful oasis of sweet tastes and friendly staff that will...
review_full: Finely positioned and maintained, Mas Al Sur is one of the prime restaurants of Madrid. Located in the Calle Santa Isabel 35 St, just north of Reina Sofia, this wonderful and crowded restaurant provides a cheerful oasis of sweet tastes and friendly staff that will keep you coming back for more. We tried a range of dishes, from kalamari to beef stakes, and were over and over stunned by the pleasantness of them; the risotto provided the prologue to what would become the best meal my family and myself had during our stay in Madrid, and as chicken, kalamari and pork followed, the closure was a selection of cakes that smelled and tasted like mum's. In fact, not only the cakes evoked that feeling; you can sense that the masters at work in the kitchen are crafting the dishes the same way they do at home. Nothing is superficial, and all is perfect. In the end, I thanked the young and charismatic owner Johnny for a wonderful evening, and told him this was the finest birthday meal I ever had, as it truly was. A couple of moments later - a plate with a lemon cake arrived at our table, with 'Happy Birthday!' written in Spanish on it. On the house, naturally. What more can I say? What a wonderful evening. Visit this place. You can thank me later.

review_preview: We attended the dinner/flamenco show at the Corral late in March. The place is quite rustic but in a charming way. Our wait staff was very good. We had a wonderful meal of langostines with lobster sauce, paella, and their famous five chocolate dessert. We...
review_full: We attended the dinner/flamenco show at the Corral late in March. The place is quite rustic but in a charming way. Our wait staff was very good. We had a wonderful meal of langostines with lobster sauce, paella, and their famous five chocolate dessert. We were fortunate to get a table right next to the stage so we could really see the dancers. There are tables there where large posts/columns partially block the view and there are tables to the right of the stage and far in back that likely have a poor view as well. This is definetly a place where you either need to reserve specific seating or arrive early to get a good table. We hadn't seen a flameco show before but we were very impressed with both the dancers and the musicians. I love Spanish guitar music and they played between each of the dances so lots of wonderful music. I can't comment on location as we were with a business group and were transported there, but we were staying at the Westin Palace and it was about a 20 minute ride to the restuarant.

title_review: Take all proof of prepayment to the show
review_preview: On our current trip to Madrid, my wife treated me to best flamenco show in town.   She booked our reservations in advance and prepaid.  Upon arrival at the venue, she presented her reservations info and within seconds, the maitre'd turned her away and said you...
review_full: On our current trip to Madrid, my wife treated me to best flamenco show in town. She booked our reservations in advance and prepaid. Upon arrival at the venue, she presented her reservations info and within seconds, the maitre'd turned her away and said you have no resrvations, and essentially "go away". She was clearly upset and protested and finally another person who spoke English came to apologize that we could not be seated, and, essentially, go away. After showing him the proof of the prepayment, he continued to protest and said he needed more proof. Finally, he rechecked the reservation and said, essentially, oops we missed your reservation. You were on the list And the maitre 'd just missed it. This was clearly not the way to begin an otherwise pleasant evening. The show was great, the service a bit disorganized, but an unfortunate way to begin a much anticipated evening.

review_preview: We arrived at Corral de la Moreria 30 minutes before the show. We had made a reservation for the show only, not for dinner. The room was about 1/4 full at the time and they placed us at a table that had not one but...
review_full: We arrived at Corral de la Moreria 30 minutes before the show. We had made a reservation for the show only, not for dinner. The room was about 1/4 full at the time and they placed us at a table that had not one but two columns blocking our view of the stage. Neither my husband nor I could see anything. We requested moving to a different table and wow, it was as if we were asking for a huge favor. No, it couldn't be done, we were told. Maybe if they weren't sold out they could move us. We asked a second person and no, he said, maybe in 10 minutes, maybe. A waiter asked for our drink order and told us once we ordered that we couldn't change seats so please order now. We said no, we would order after we moved. Finally we were moved to a table at the front corner of the stage. One of us could see, the other still had an obstructed view.   In hindsight, EVERY table has a pretty bad view. Most are obstructed to some degree. Maybe I'm not a flamenco lover, but I never would know that because this was my first experience with it. The dance and music were great, but know that the dance is loud and the singing is over-modulated. This place might have great reviews but their attitude towards us was quite poor. We felt taken advantage of as tourists, which is strange considering the number of tourists in the venue.

review_preview: I'd like to start off by saying that my weekend in Spain, was made entirely memorable due to coming here.I had arrived with my parents after wandering aimlessly around Madrid for a place to eat. We were greeted with nothing but smiles. We had...
review_full: I'd like to start off by saying that my weekend in Spain, was made entirely memorable due to coming here. I had arrived with my parents after wandering aimlessly around Madrid for a place to eat. We were greeted with nothing but smiles. We had not made a reservation, (highly recommend to make one) but because of this, we were sat down at the bar on front of the kitchen. To be able to sit in front of the kitchen, is considered the best seat in the house in my opinion. After being guided to our seats, we immediately felt at home as we were attended by both the bartender and server, (Fredrick and Vanessa respectively). The casual demeanor they both had, left all of us completely melt in comfort by them as they patiently and attentively aided us through the menu. Immediately describing the dishes with thorough knowledge, as well as describing the vision of the business cleverly seen through the decor. All 3 of us ordered a different cocktail and to our surprise of different flavour profiles, each one shinned in its meticulous understanding of ingredients and balance that was felt on the palate.  We started of with the croquettes; crunchy, soft, gooey with a kick of iberico ham worked perfectly.  Quickly followed by the tuna Tataki, which brightly showcased understanding of local ingredients with perfect respect of Japanese techniques.  What followed was a glass dome filled with a swirling cloud of curiosity. It was a fish dish; skin seared, topped with wakame and a side of a ratatouille as it's known in French cuisine. With nothing to hide behind, confidence of the chef could be seen intermingled with an ocean saltiness and the perfect pairing of what I could assume was Applewood smoke. The final dish that we tried was the Bao bun with iberico. What I was completely blown away by was the sauce. The perfect balance on all areas of the palate, left no room for the tongue to make sense of it all. Sweet, sour, salty, umami flavour permeated throughout the dish with the bun completing the balance with an underlying sweetness that lingered throughout the dish. This place showcases the influences the inhabitants of Madrid. It is a restaurant that you cannot leave Madrid without trying.

title_review: Incredible food with a friendly chill atmosphere...
review_preview: Everytime I'm in Madrid I make an effort to go to one place... Inclan. Hands down, one of  the best restaurants in town!! I haven't had a bad thing here yet actually. From the mouth watering meats, to the burrata with a syringe of pesto...
review_full: Everytime I'm in Madrid I make an effort to go to one place... Inclan. Hands down, one of the best restaurants in town!! I haven't had a bad thing here yet actually. From the mouth watering meats, to the burrata with a syringe of pesto to fill it with, and my personal favorite, the aromatic, tender and flavorful Octopus... I dream of it regularly. To be honest its a rather busy spot that isn't incredibly large. In fact the last two times I visited, it was busy and full but being solo in the city I was able to secure a spot at the small bar and at a small table the other time. So be warned, make a reservation to secure a spot or go during lunch time. Rocio is the sweetest and will take good care of you and tolerate your awful Spanish;) And one of the managers Alex was on top of it and helped me feel like the regular I want to be!!!

review_full: We went for both lunch and dinner. The dinner service was much more busy, however the food still arrived within 20 minutes of ordering. Will be heading back again as the prices range from 6 euro for a half (which is a generous serve) and 15 euro for a seafood paella. Well worth a visit.

title_review: Best tapas so far in Spain
review_preview: Found this while wandering the streets and liked the varying dishes on the menu. Came in and had the sangria, Mediterranea salad and grilled octopus. The sangria was phenomenal and not too sweet. The salad was the perfect mix of sweet from the fruit and...
review_full: Found this while wandering the streets and liked the varying dishes on the menu. Came in and had the sangria, Mediterranea salad and grilled octopus. The sangria was phenomenal and not too sweet. The salad was the perfect mix of sweet from the fruit and salty with the olives and refreshing with mint. The star of the show was the grilled octopus in chimichurri sauce. Wow. Very reasonable and Peter was a great help/server. Highly recommend. Had multiple dinners in Barcelona and Mallorca, but this took the cake. Nice atmosphere and amazing value.

The rose sangria was unusual but really refreshing. All the staff were very polite and were keen to explain each dish. I asked for a dessert recommendation and they suggested the chocolate cake with violet ice cream. It was amazing. My friend left some of his food because he was full and they wanted to check if there was a problem and offered to replace it if he did nt like it. I thought that was a very thoughtful touch. Would definitely recommend.

title_review: Hit or miss tapas, but great service
review_preview: My husband and I went here for a nice quiet dinner (request "la cueva,' the little cave-like back room with exposed brick). You can make a reservation on their website--just follow the link on TA's listing and select "English" to make the reservation. The food...
review_full: My husband and I went here for a nice quiet dinner (request "la cueva,' the little cave-like back room with exposed brick). You can make a reservation on their website--just follow the link on TA's listing and select "English" to make the reservation. The food was good--mostly tapas but more substantial than your typical tapas joint--and the service was excellent. Our server, Angel, was wonderful. The place was really empty (we went on a Wednesday around 9:30) which I found odd..and the other parties were a group of British people and a German couple, so obviously they found this place on TA just like I did! But this place isn't a tourist place...it's definitely good food and authentic. One little complaint--they should lower the lighting and also play more unassuming music (they were playing American pop--not exactly romantic to listen to Pink!). The marinated tomatoes were delicious! So was the plate of roasted vegetables with a dipping sauce (can you tell I'm a vegetarian?). My husband eats meat and got some other dishes, but they were hit or miss--some we really loved and some were just so-so. Maybe we didn't order the right dishes. It's over by the Palacio Real, so definitely walkable. But it's a little bit off the beaten path so if you're going to take a cab home, ask them to call you one before you leave--otherwise, walk toward the Palacio and you'll find one soon enough. I have to say I'm surprised this is rated so high considering all the restaurants in Madrid, but it was a good experience and I'd go back.

I ordered the entrecot which was really great. The grilled vegetables which was normal. Do try the jamon serrano though. Very good quality, it almost melts in your mouth.  The staff were very friendly and spoke english. And ambiance of the place is more updated/modern than the normal spanish bar/restaurants found near sol.   I'd say you could get all of this stuff in a normal spanish restaurant. I think because it's in opera in a more touristy area, they're allowed to charge a bit extra.

review_preview: I'd probably give this a place a 5 for food, but I took one away for the bizarre encounter I had.Convenient location to a couple tourist attractions, we were seated in the brick cellar area located in the basement.  The waiter spoke good English...
review_full: I'd probably give this a place a 5 for food, but I took one away for the bizarre encounter I had. Convenient location to a couple tourist attractions, we were seated in the brick cellar area located in the basement. The waiter spoke good English and gave a little speech on how everything on the menu was so great and the best in Madrid etc. Included in this speech was the 1/4 roasted goat which they must do 1 a night. Anyways, I started to order a few things because I wanted to try a variety and he cut me off. He said "that is too much, you will waste it, and we don't waste food here... I will only give you 1/2 portions etc" I was a bit shocked because I feel it's my prerogative to order whatever I wanted. After this extremely awkward interaction, I was allowed to order the foie, fried padron peppers, tomatoes (with arguably the best olive oil I've ever had) and the hake cheeks. About 1/2 way through the meal, I asked the waiter if the goat was still available, and he replied yes. I then asked him to send it to the table and he got right on it. I had to explain I was just joking, but funny how he was going to send over the most expensive item on the menu after his earlier lecture. This place has good food... just be prepared to be rebuffed it you try to order a lot of food. Guess he's not used to the American appetite.

review_preview: Family restaurant - like so many other visitors we returned night after night.  Found it through reviews here and it well deserves the praise given by others.  Madrid was unseasonably warm (we were told) so we eat out every night on the street (5% extra...
review_full: Family restaurant - like so many other visitors we returned night after night. Found it through reviews here and it well deserves the praise given by others. Madrid was unseasonably warm (we were told) so we eat out every night on the street (5% extra to eat on the terrace) and we met the famous David that others rave about, but we found the other staff members just as good! First night Hake, excellent but the table next door had the Jamon Iberico and the Paella - so we returned the following day to have exactly that and it was great, so on our third night, the last night we returned again to have the Presa - a cut of pork which some rate as the equivalent of Wagyu beef - and it was sensational. The family also own the shop next door which supplies the restaurant with Olive Oil but in particular the Jamon - and from the reserved legs in the shop they also supply a lot of the other top Tapas bars in Madrid. On our last afternoon we went to the shop and bought some Jamon to take home - only wish now we'd bought more.

title_review: A Nice Place but food not quite as expected
review_preview: I had great expectations for this restaurant and I can certainly say that the staff were very friendly and the waiter extremely informative.  I wasn't entirely sure whether he was trying to up-sell at first but on reflection I think he was just passionate about...
review_full: I had great expectations for this restaurant and I can certainly say that the staff were very friendly and the waiter extremely informative. I wasn't entirely sure whether he was trying to up-sell at first but on reflection I think he was just passionate about the local produce. The Squid dish I ordered as a main was a little too salty for my palate and my husband's quarter goatling the same but the Canadian on the next table said his was "to die for" and it certainly didn't stop me eating all of mine. The rioja was divine and the olive oil like no other virgin olive oil I've tasted. Tapas (a selection of iberian meats) a little disappointing as a starter but nevertheless tasty. I would go again but would probably choose more carefully and ask for no added salt as I do think on my dish particularly this was an addition after cooking as I could see the salt crystals.

review_full: Having read fabulous reviews on Trip Advisor and as it was close to our hotel, ApartoSuites Jardines de Sabatini we gave La Mi Venta a late night visit on our arrival in Madrid. We were ushered into the wine cellar and greeted by Angel, who hailed from Toledo. The four of us shared two platters of tapas along with the fantastic house red. We were so impressed with the food and service that we had no hesitation in booking a table there for our final evening. The night turned out to be a gastronomic delight with goatling (tasting like tender lamb) and the desert speciality....Passion Fruit Soup, a delicious palate cleanser.  The quality of the food was perfectly matched with the superb  service of our waiters: Angel, Jose and Guilliermo. Can't wait to return!!!

title_review: The absolute best menu del d√≠a in Madrid
review_preview: I've visited InClan at least 5 times during my study abroad period in Madrid and it has proved to be the absolute best place for a menu del d√≠a. The service has been tremendous every single time. The waiters (Alejandro, Salvador) are good at what...
review_full: I've visited InClan at least 5 times during my study abroad period in Madrid and it has proved to be the absolute best place for a menu del d√≠a. The service has been tremendous every single time. The waiters (Alejandro, Salvador) are good at what they do and regularly check in to see if everything is okay. They go out of their way to make sure you have a wonderful time. I once visited with a vegetarian friend and even though the menu del d√≠a doesn't offer a vegetarian option as a segundo normally they made her a vegetarian risotto (which she loved so much!!). Another time I went with a friend who wanted iced tea (bot not the soda-one) so they brought him a glass with ice and a cup of hot tea, all served with a smile. Besides all that the open kitchen is great, the food is always tremendous and the interior looks beautiful. A few recommendations: - Whenever they have risotto on the menu del d√≠a, go for it. It's so, so, so good. All of the different varieties. Just perfect. - Fish!!! The bacalao and tuna at InClan are the most delicious ones I've had in all of Madrid.  And I'll never get enough of the crumbled brownie with ice cream as a dessert. Their menu del d√≠a costs only ‚Ç¨12,90 which is incredibly cheap for the value you get. The products are of high quality, the service great, the setting lovely. Thanks InClan for the many many wonderful meals.

review_preview: I booked through el tenedor for a Sunday night meal with a friend, hoping for a nice pleasant evening, but I'm afraid we left with a bad taste in our mouths. I felt we were treated fairly badly by the waiting staff, especially when we...
review_full: I booked through el tenedor for a Sunday night meal with a friend, hoping for a nice pleasant evening, but I'm afraid we left with a bad taste in our mouths. I felt we were treated fairly badly by the waiting staff, especially when we witnessed how other groups were treated. Discount cards, chupitos and pledges for good reviews on TripAdvisor were dished out aplenty to neighboring tables. We were given watered-down wine (when I highlighted this to the staff, they had to go retrieve more of the wine from the cellar/store room, which confirmed to me that they had only a little left and tried to rob me off with putting some water in it. Just rude) we also had none of the pleasantries indicated above; and we're not difficult people. The food was nice but the evening was completely overshadowed by the fact we were largely ignored and then treated with disdain when we did have dealings with the staff. A very bizarre restaurant experience, and not in the cool, trying to be bizarre way.

review_preview: I've pondered long and hard on this one. It's taken me three days to decide on my review. The waiter, David, was enthusiastic and extremely knowledgable about the menu and his produce. He brought the steaks out for us to look at before we ordered....
review_full: I've pondered long and hard on this one. It's taken me three days to decide on my review. The waiter, David, was enthusiastic and extremely knowledgable about the menu and his produce. He brought the steaks out for us to look at before we ordered. I had a sense however of up selling. I wasn't sure he was not trying to get us to buy more expensive dishes. Not sure. I don't think in hindsight it was the right place to take teenagers. The menu was limited for them to choose and this made for a more difficult selection for us all. We found some of the food very salty which may have been our palates but three of us thought it.  The venue in the cellar downstairs was beautiful but lacked atmosphere and had we been a couple alone I would have wanted moving upstairs simply for more company.  I do believe the ingredients were exceptional and the best they can source particularly the olive oil. Wow. And the house wine was fab.  I'm just left in two minds.  I could not fault the service. Truly 5 star. The food possibly more 3 therefore I settled on 4.

title_review: Went twice within our 5 days in Madrid
review_preview: We took a walk from our hotel when we first arrived and ended up at La Mi Venta for lunch. It is a charming delightful find! Everything was delicious and the service was wonderful!Our last night we had planned to go somewhere else and...
review_full: We took a walk from our hotel when we first arrived and ended up at La Mi Venta for lunch. It is a charming delightful find! Everything was delicious and the service was wonderful! Our last night we had planned to go somewhere else and then found out the restaurant was closed on Sunday. Since we were very close to La Mi Venta we figured we'd try it for dinner. The only downside was we couldn't sit outside. But their dining rooms downstairs are lovely. Again the meal was delicious and the service wonderful! The hake was amazing and I ate every last bite! One friend has a burger and loved it, and another ordered two Pinchos - which were very large for appetizers and delicious - I had them for lunch the first time! My husband had the cod and couldn't finish it. They are not shy with portion size. Unfortunately we left no room for dessert which I am sure would also have been amazing!

review_preview: This restaurant has two gems: its amazing selection of meat, and the wonderful David, who is just brimming with knowledge about the food here. We had the foie, a charcuterie platter (some of the chorizo were out of this world!), fried queso in salmorejo, and...
review_full: This restaurant has two gems: its amazing selection of meat, and the wonderful David, who is just brimming with knowledge about the food here.  We had the foie, a charcuterie platter (some of the chorizo were out of this world!), fried queso in salmorejo, and what you must absolutely order if you come here: the Iberian pork. I suppose we could have done some research beforehand, but no worries if you don't - David explains the magic of Iberian pork just fine (which is that selected pigs are purely acorn-fed six months before their slaughter). He described the pork as "something amazing, like no meat you've ever had before," and it was true. It's hard to describe, other than say it is worth coming here to try.  The above dishes, along with a bottle of the house rioja and tax, came up to around 75 euros.

review_preview: It was a rainy, cold December evening, and we were looking for a place to have some caldo (simple warm beef broth) in order to warm the bones.  My girlfriend stepped in to see if they had some warm broth, as I looked through the...
review_full: It was a rainy, cold December evening, and we were looking for a place to have some caldo (simple warm beef broth) in order to warm the bones. My girlfriend stepped in to see if they had some warm broth, as I looked through the front window, I saw him nod with a sense of satisfaction. I immediately walked in with a certain desire to shake that December chill. The decor of this little cozy bar, which has a big dining room in the basement, is rustic and homey. The wooden beams give that country old school feel that makes you want to buck up to the bar and order a winter broth, then a red wine and some tasty tapas. The broth was excellent, not too salty, with a strong beefy taste with a touch of onion, garlic, and bay leaf to warm the stomach and the heart. After the broth, we ordered two house Riojas for 2.20‚Ç¨. Nothing special, but more that adequate.  We asked for the bill, they didn't include the broths. We asked the waiter, and he told us it was on the house. What a nice touch! They have a wood grill and stove to prepare all those typical meat dishes, including suckling piglet, which I'm sure is out of this world. I will definitely go back for lunch on a cold February day.

We found this place online and it was better than any expectations we had. It was a real treat for us and a very special experience. Really delicious, local produce without fussy sauces or added flavours. If you want to try proper Spanish food, I'd recommend this place in a second. Trust David, the waiter, and he will advise you and recommend something to suit. He was very honest and has a no-nonsense approach to food, which I love. All in all, good food, good wine, lovely staff, nice clean restaurant. What more could you want?

title_review: Modern tapas, welcoming service and value
review_preview: We went to Inclan Brutal for a quick lunch before seeing a movie. For a weekend lunch, reservations are advisable and were easily made online the morning of. The staff from servers to management were warm, welcoming and happy to explain the menu. Alex specifically...
review_full: We went to Inclan Brutal for a quick lunch before seeing a movie. For a weekend lunch, reservations are advisable and were easily made online the morning of. The staff from servers to management were warm, welcoming and happy to explain the menu. Alex specifically chatted us up and gave us great recommendations - he is a super host. We tried four plates and a jar of sangria. The pulpo and bao were strong dishes with great presentation and taste. The Q de Pato was the star dish, and I would return just to have this again.  The atmosphere is active and servers were rapidly dropping off plates and drinks for all tables, and hosts routinely checked to see how all were doing. There is definitely a more international feel at Inclan than typical Spanish tapas, and I would describe Inclan as a more modern spin on tapas itself, as well as customer engagement and service. Forty euros for four plates and a jar of sangria is a phenomenal value anywhere around Sol or even the less touristic areas of Madrid. We will be back for sure.

title_review: A Gem in Madrid near Palacio Real
review_preview: Thank you TripAdvisor.com! While in Madrid, we looked for the highest rated restaurant near our hotel - and found this gem just a few blocks away.La Mi Venta is very unassuming from the outside - it looks like a thousand other touristy street cafes...
review_full: Thank you TripAdvisor.com! While in Madrid, we looked for the highest rated restaurant near our hotel - and found this gem just a few blocks away. La Mi Venta is very unassuming from the outside - it looks like a thousand other touristy street cafes in this area near the Palacio Real. But inside is another matter. The ground floor is a very nondescript tapas bar - but downstairs are two very intimate and lovely dining rooms. David, who presides over this area like a king, is assisted by a young man who's name we did not get, but the two compliment each other beautifully.  After being served a delicious bread and an amazing olive oil for dipping, we opted for tapas - two of the combination plates that evening. The menu includes a number of Tapas selections, plus other small plates, salads, and larger meals at the back. Our first Tapas Platter was a combination of Iberico Jamon (reputed to be the best in Madrid - and I have no argument there), and other charcuterie with Manchengo cheese. At David's recommendation, we ordered a bottle of 2010 Pago de Carraovejas Riserva Tinto. A blend of 97% Temperanillo, 2% Cabernet Sauvignon, and 1% Merlot - a truly superlative wine (Parker - 94 Points) for only 44 Euros. The wine was a perfect accompaniment to the Tapas. For our second platter, we chose a seafood base - Pike, tuna, foie gras, and Pork back with fried potatoes and mild chilies. All amazing. The Spanish foie gras (which won the French competition last year) is very light and delicious and the geese are not force-fed to produce this amazing product. We had digestives at the end of the meal, a version of limoncello and a chocolate cream liquor with wonderful confections.  The entire bill with tax was 84 Euros. This restaurant is a don't miss if you are visiting Madrid,

review_full: Whilst trying to source lunch in madrid centre and seeing the usual selection of tapas type places we came across this restaurant and notices their menu del Dias. This was really great quality and excellent value for money. Under 13 euros for 3 courses and a drink. The starters we're a choice of gazpacho, a ham,cheese and pineapple salad, or a mushroom risotto. Between the four of us we tried all these and were very impressed, especially the risotto. Mains we're a choice of pork with a cheese sauce, chicken with peppers or take. Again all three were had were decent sized portions and very tasty. A choice of four puddings had me pixkomg a green tea panecotta (don't be put off by the colour), a brownie with ice cream, and two others which slip my mind as the other members if our party had them but all we're reported backbas top notch. Big shout out to Robert our host who was a great help as while the main menu has an English version the menu of the day was in Spanish only and he did a great job translating for us. All in all much better food for a fraction of the price it would have cost for the standard ham, cheese, croquettes, etc in the main plazas.

title_review: Be careful of your seat choice and more.
review_preview: If you want dinner theater experience (and I dont mean that in a positive way) for a lot of money then go here. But be forewarned you will be jammed into the restaurant so tightly that the servers will brush you every time they walk...
review_full: If you want dinner theater experience (and I dont mean that in a positive way) for a lot of money then go here. But be forewarned you will be jammed into the restaurant so tightly that the servers will brush you every time they walk by you. Also, the dining room is set up in an L-shape and the performers play 95% to one direction. Be sure you are at a table in the part of the L closest to the entrance or you will be looking at the performers sides and miss their faces. In addition, we were on the wrong side of the L and there were so many people positioning themselves to see better that we could only see the performers from the waist up. Kind of missing the fact that we missed part of the show which is seeing their legs and feet. Lastly, the meal service we had was so bad they ended up giving us 50% without us asking. That's when you know you're right to be disappointed-- the management could see it. People were being served dessert and we had not even had our entrees. I had to stop a waiter and in my best Spanglish tell him that we had not even been served our dinner. Every step of the way it was stopping them and asking for the next course. My recommendation is that you seek out bars and restaurants that have flamenco as part of their regular service. When we did find it, it was much more from the heart and rich in vitality instead of from a venue that puts the same damn show on 2 times a night almost every night of the year. You will save a ton of money and have a better time.

title_review: Great Start or Finish to your trip to Madrid

You have to pay for the show (39 euros) on top of the meal cost, but it's worth it for a special treat. It is very cramped so be aware of that, but it adds to the atmosphere. The Flamenco was outstanding, especially the male dancer (Jesus Fernandez) who was spell binding. The hotel made our reservation for us and that made it all very easy. We went for the early show which was quite good as it gave us more time to concentrate on the dancing. We went on the last night of our trip which was a.great way to end the holiday.

review_preview: We went to this dinner and show on our last night in Madrid.  We both felt the food was excellent and I literally licked the plate clean after each course.  We had the set menus.  I had the ‚Ç¨39.90 menu and my husband had the...
review_full: We went to this dinner and show on our last night in Madrid. We both felt the food was excellent and I literally licked the plate clean after each course. We had the set menus. I had the ‚Ç¨39.90 menu and my husband had the ‚Ç¨59.90 set menu (and I think I enjoyed mine more). The cost also included some alcohol. We felt the dinner was very good value. The show was also good and we really appreciate the technical aspects of it. Due to the structure of the restaurant some parts are hard to see and there were times that the performers were explaining things but we could not hear what they were saying. These dishes were well worth the price as they presented your mouth with wonderfully different tastes.

title_review: Wow wow wow 'Corral de la Moreria' thank you so much for making my 40th birthday so unforgettable!!!
review_preview: Friday 10th August.So i had 6 of my friends coming over from London for my big 40th birthday celebrations and wanted the weekend to have a Spanish flavour....what better way than to have Flamenco feature in the celebrations.Flamenco at the 'Corral de la...
review_full: Friday 10th August. So i had 6 of my friends coming over from London for my big 40th birthday celebrations and wanted the weekend to have a Spanish flavour....what better way than to have Flamenco feature in the celebrations. Flamenco at the 'Corral de la Moreria' came highly recommended so i booked 7 tickets for my evening birthday celebrations for show and a drink!  The staff at the venue had saved me the best table for me and my friends which was so special. i was right in front of the stage. I have never seen Flamenco live before and all i can say is that it was awesome. I don't speak any Spanish but the emotion and interplay between the dancers, guitar players and the singers was incredible, it just draws you in. How these amazing stars of Flamenco move their feet so fast is beyond me i was absolutely captivated by their performance and totally in awe. Midway through the show one of the beautiful dancers announced that it was someones birthday........mine. what happened next was totally unexpected. All the dancers, musicians and singers all gathered at the front of the stage and sang happy birthday to me in Spanish flamenco style....truely awesome and unforgettable. it was like stopping a theatre production midway....amazing!! They really made me feel like i was the only one watching the show:-) As they finished singing they brought me out a birthday cake.:-) Then two of the dancers came to our table again and wanted me and my friend to join them on stage to dance Flamenco alongside them.....at first i was hesitant but as there were two of us i felt brave!! How amazing was that. Was i embarrassed up there.... hell no!! All you want to do after watching the show is just try out Flamenco....lolololol. We were dancing alongside these amazing well known performers. Dear 'Corral de la Moreria' all i can say thank you for an incredible evening. My friends and i have pinpointed this evening as one of the highlights of my birthday weekend. How thoughtful you all are, what lovely friendly smiles you gave me as you sang Happy Birthday and thank you for giving me an introduction to Flamenco.....i am now hooked!! If you are reading this and thinking about whether to go to the show or not (as i did before going) dont think about it, just book it!! You'll have an amazing evening:-)xx

review_preview: On our last night in Spain (after a 2-week trip) we had dinner at Taverna Mas al Sur. 5 of us dined and enjoyed everything we ordered. The menu had an interesting mix of tapas, salads, and appetizers such as moussaka. We tried the moussaka,...
review_full: On our last night in Spain (after a 2-week trip) we had dinner at Taverna Mas al Sur. 5 of us dined and enjoyed everything we ordered. The menu had an interesting mix of tapas, salads, and appetizers such as moussaka. We tried the moussaka, which was good. We had a delicious salad with a hard goat cheese, mixed greens, and some other yummy ingredients (that I can't specifically remember). We also ordered both mushroom and ham croquettes, which were great. We also had the rope vieja--yummy. But the best item was the risotto. It was the perfect texture, with nice chunky mushrooms, and a sprinkling of crispy bacon (or some type of Spanish pork) on top. As usual, we ordered way to much food, but we had a great time and enjoyed everything. The servers were very friendly & efficient, too.

review_preview: Ok. I am Spanish. I detest flamenco. But this actually turned out to be quite ok, if pricey...Food:Good but way overpriced. You have an open menu and you have set menus. The cheapest set menu starts at 40‚Ç¨... the most expensive... forget it!...
review_full: Ok. I am Spanish. I detest flamenco. But this actually turned out to be quite ok, if pricey... Food: Good but way overpriced. You have an open menu and you have set menus. The cheapest set menu starts at 40‚Ç¨... the most expensive... forget it! I had a mushroom cream with foie gras and spanish ham. It was quite good. The entrecote steak was cooked to my request. It was juicy and yummy. Dessert was lemon sorbet. This was part of the 40 euro menu. Service was prompt, helpful and friendly. Just perfect. The quality of the food was good and it was very well prepared but at Spanish prices this was way too expensive. But you do not really pay for the food but mostly to be seated there and watch the show. This brings me to the show: You actually purchase the show separately: 42 Euros per person. The show is flamenco dancers, male and female, singer and guitar players. All in all the show was quite good and it had a very good energy. We were sitting near the dancers at table 15, quite a good one. Not too close and not too far. As exciting as it may seem to you, please do not take there kids under 10... both the kids and the rest of the people spending over $ 100 will be thankful. There were two tables right next to me with kids that age and it was seriously unbearable. Kids at 11 PM should be in bed because they are tired, they yell, they complain, they play with their gameboy consoles at full volume (I actually had to ask the mother to shut the thing up) All in all, I think it is something I would recommend for someone visiting our country if they do not have time to head down to Andalucia. This place is touristy but its fame is deserved, the show was good.

review_full: I was on a business trip with a friend and we looked for a nice place to eat near our Hostal. And we found a gem!! It is true - the waitors mainly do not know English but they make up for it by being very friendly and helpful. A tip for guests from Balkans - one of the staff knows Serbian! We had dinner here for 3 days and had lunch once - everything we ate was very tasty (recommend the squid, cod with goat cheese and honey, garlic shrimp and passion fruit cake). They have great wine and try the summer wine ( tinto verano!). Also, I recommed going here for lunch because for 10-15‚Ç¨ you can get a starter, main dish, dessert and drink! Will be back here when I return to Madrid!

title_review: Totally lived up to the great reviews!
review_preview: First night and very first dinner ever, in Madrid and I was very impressed. We are staying in the Atocha area, so the walk was less than a mile and a pleasant walk at that. Was surprised and excited to see how vibrant the city...
review_full: First night and very first dinner ever, in Madrid and I was very impressed. We are staying in the Atocha area, so the walk was less than a mile and a pleasant walk at that. Was surprised and excited to see how vibrant the city was at 9 pm. My partner and I walked in and was put on a wait list, note that the space is not small it is tiny and extremely narrow. After about 20 minutes a space opened up at the bar and we decided to take full advantage. We started with a pint of the most delicious sangria that I have ever had, seriously good. We opted to order a few tapas, a full portion of the tempura salmon. At the end, we had to decided to order another portion of the garlic shrimp and some spinach quiche. The food was fresh and did not lack in flavor, we were literally speechless by what we had just experienced. The guy at the bar spoke zero English but he was so polite and we managed with my minimal butchered version of Spanish. Will definitely dine here again if given the chance. I held off on a full five rating due to the space and the wait, otherwise no complaints.

review_preview: O Restaurant, how many things are wrong with you? Let us count them...- When the hearing server was offered our phone translator app to communicate with us, he said he would get someone who speaks English. As if that would be more helpful? Before...
review_full: O Restaurant, how many things are wrong with you? Let us count them... - When the hearing server was offered our phone translator app to communicate with us, he said he would get someone who speaks English. As if that would be more helpful? Before that, he actually read my question and then turned to the other person and began, "So he asked this and the answer is..." -- which we can only interpret as an indication that he thinks Deaf people are inferior customers. - The other server very stubbornly kept speaking to answer our questions until we had to explicitly gesture for his mouth to stop and his fingers to start typing. - This new server did not know the menu and had to ask the kitchen several times. Our questions were very basic - what is in the risotto? What does this particular name mean? Etc. - Although water is not automatically served in most restaurants, we were not even offered the option and thus went without it for our entire meal. - The first server brought our salads and again continued to ignore the communication needs that had been expressed, instead verbally announcing which dishes were which. - Our starters and mains were served together, which we didn't expect and weren't asked if we would prefer them served in sequence. We were used to other European restaurants so it's possible this is how they do it, but we simply weren't warned. - The shrimp main dish was a questionable creation to be priced at ‚Ç¨5,20 because it essentially was four small shrimp served in a cast iron plate of oil. It did not taste bad, but it most certainly did not belong at a price point anywhere above ‚Ç¨2. - When we sent the shrimp dish back and informed them we would order another main, we ended up never getting a new menu to do this. Eventually I had to get up and take one from the server station myself, and saw that two other servers were idle in another section of the restaurant. (We ended up not ordering anything else as we were too frustrated and disappointed with the portion sizes of other dishes described to us.) - When our last dishes were taken away, we weren't told we had to go to the bar to pay, and since it wasn't visible from our section, we had no visual clues until we actually got up in frustration after 15 minutes and discovered how to pay.  - The shrimp dish was still on the first bill given to us. They did remove it, but at this point: honestly? Really? Don't go here. We are sorry to the owners who probably work hard to stay afloat in the business, but they simply need to get the basic issues addressed ASAP. Staff training and a redesigned menu are the best place to start.

The service was fantastic and we were very well taken care of and John was so friendly and patient in explaining everything on the menu (since none of us know any Spanish!), despite having a million things to do; his passion for providing good food and service is clearly evident and having so many positive reviews after only 7 months of operating is a testament to that. We have dined at a couple of other restaurants on tripadvisor's top 10 in Madrid, and they have all faired pretty average compared to El Sur. We are definitely looking forward to coming back to madrid and eating here, we just hope we'll still be able to get a table, coz a little gem like this will no doubt be very popular in no time!

We were there on the early side for Spain, but it was filling up by the time we left.

review_preview: On our first visit to Madrid with our 20 year old daughters, we were struggling to decide if we should visit Corral de la Moreria.  We definitely wanted to see a flamenco show, but we are generally not fans of the typical touristy destinations. We...
review_full: On our first visit to Madrid with our 20 year old daughters, we were struggling to decide if we should visit Corral de la Moreria. We definitely wanted to see a flamenco show, but we are generally not fans of the typical touristy destinations. We were also debating whether to eat there or just go for the show and drinks. For the sake of ease, we opted to eat dinner at the show. The food was quite good. Not spectacular and probably a bit over priced, but all in all, very good. The service was first rate. Our waiter happily substituted sangria instead of wine for my daughters at no charge. As for the show, we didn't have anything to compare it to, never having seen a Flamenco show, but all 4 of us thought it was terrific. The intensity and skill of the dancers was quite entertaining As other's have said, it is not an inexpensive evening, but in our view it was well worth it.

title_review: Intense flamenco makes a great late night choice
review_preview: We went here on the spur of the moment after eating dinner a few blocks away. We arrived about 10:45 and lined up for what turned out to be the 11:30pm show. At the door it became obvious almost everyone else had a booking but...
review_full: We went here on the spur of the moment after eating dinner a few blocks away. We arrived about 10:45 and lined up for what turned out to be the 11:30pm show. At the door it became obvious almost everyone else had a booking but we got lucky and were fitted in towards the back but raised up a step so the view was good. The actual venue looks tired but once seated it doesn't matter since it's dark. The crowd seems to be split between tourists and local aficionados, who were good at shssing the disrespectful. We didn't eat and only bought an extra bottle of water and one beer, the total was 102 euros. I am a neophyte at flamenco so have no idea whether the performances constituted "good" or even great flamenco but the singers poured out emotion, the guitar players sizzled and the feet action of the dancers was tiring to watch, I can only speculate how it must hurt to perform at that intensity and duration. As a show it was a great performance.

title_review: No doubt, the best Flamenco in Madrid. Most probably in the world :)
review_preview: No, I was NOT a Flamenco lover previously. However, the 75 minutes of hiq show have simply flown away, leaving but goose bumps all over my skin and even tears every now and then. Of course it is not cheap, but Madrid has lots of...
review_full: No, I was NOT a Flamenco lover previously. However, the 75 minutes of hiq show have simply flown away, leaving but goose bumps all over my skin and even tears every now and then. Of course it is not cheap, but Madrid has lots of cheap flamenco shows around Puerta del Sol. High quality and refinement need to be appreciated by a higher price. However, it's worthy and I will repeat this enriching experience. Another plus for the location, the friendly waiters and the food. A wider variety of the tasty Spanish cervezas could add, but I intend to suggest it next time I am there. title_review: Outstanding display of Spanish beauty, tradition and talent.
review_preview: The title of this review says it all. My wife and I have promised ourselves a Flamenco evening for many a year...and our first visit to Madrid provided the perfect opportunity. After much internet research and local advice, we settled on Corral de la Moreria....
review_full: The title of this review says it all. My wife and I have promised ourselves a Flamenco evening for many a year...and our first visit to Madrid provided the perfect opportunity. After much internet research and local advice, we settled on Corral de la Moreria. We knew it was not going to be cheap, so were not shocked at the 100 Euro per head cost of the meal with a show. The meal was extremely good, and the wine that is served with each fixed menu is a perfect match. The service was outstanding...a special mention to Diego, our dedicated waiter for the evening...a true star..! As the desserts are served, so the dancing starts. There is not enough space here to list all of the superlatives that could be used to describe the show...suffice to say, it was truly breathtaking. The energy and soul of the dancers, both male and female, could be sensed in the room. Mesmerizing. If you accept the fact that an evening here will not be cheap...if you can look beyond the fact that the venue is a bit of a tourist trap...you will find the main event truly captivating. Go on...treat yourself. You'll not regret it.

title_review: Absolutely great food and show - but expensive
review_preview: This restaurant in downtown Madrid, few minutes from the Royal Palace, has allegedly a reputation for being "the best tablao [restaurant with flamenco show] of the world". I am not entirely sure of this; the place is really small and, together with a crowded attendance,...
review_full: This restaurant in downtown Madrid, few minutes from the Royal Palace, has allegedly a reputation for being "the best tablao [restaurant with flamenco show] of the world". I am not entirely sure of this; the place is really small and, together with a crowded attendance, this means only a very small stage (with few performers) and packed tables. I have seen much better, from this point of view, even in Madrid itself. However, I cannot find fault at all with the quality of the show and its intensity, which were amazing. The real surprise was with the food, which was gorgeous; the chef in the kitchen knows what he's doing. You are probably going to end up asking for one of the fixed menus (this is also a way to speed up the service to times compatible with the live performance); this means not very much choice of dishes, but everything we tried was delicious. I was particularly impressed by the mushroom soup, with a unique bitter flavour, by the sea bass and by the lamb. The wine (you are entitled to half a bottle per person, or more in the gourmet menu) was also excellent. A sad note was the price, definitely inflated, even for such a great experience. Reservation required - and better reserve early if you're going in the weekends.

title_review: Great find near our Airbnb Apartment
review_preview: Had a very nice meal at Tabernacle Mas Al Sur after reading other good reviews on TripAdvisor. Others reviews were on mark as my wife and I had a delicious dinner her after a long and wonderful day of exploring Madrid. Our servers, William and...
review_full: Had a very nice meal at Tabernacle Mas Al Sur after reading other good reviews on TripAdvisor. Others reviews were on mark as my wife and I had a delicious dinner her after a long and wonderful day of exploring Madrid. Our servers, William and Henry were very helpful to couple of Americans who could navigate the language with much difficulty. In spite of our challenges they both made us feel at home this evening and served us a wonderful dinner with some recommended local specialties. The shaved beef on homemade chips and the seasoned pork loin on potatoes with delicious reduction on top were excellent. Before this we tried their Cesar salad and although the dressing was not the typical Cesar dressing we get in the US, it was very good and the salad components were all fresh. All was accompanied by some delicious wine selections that Henry recommended for our meal. To top all this off, William offered us a shot of Doramas Arehucas, a tasty honey like liqueur as desert. I highly recommend this restaurant to others visiting this area of Madrid. A gem of a find.

title_review: There are better Flamenco venues in Madrid
review_preview: I was recently in Madrid with my wife and, as lovers of flamenco, we followed TA reviews for Corral De Moreria. Surprisingly, given that they accommodate about 200 plus people per show, the performers, food and service were very good. My main complaint stems from...
review_full: I was recently in Madrid with my wife and, as lovers of flamenco, we followed TA reviews for Corral De Moreria. Surprisingly, given that they accommodate about 200 plus people per show, the performers, food and service were very good. My main complaint stems from the fact that the staff is so busy serving customers and collecting payment during the show that they are constantly blocking the view of the stage. Again, the staff is delightful but the venue is such that they block the view of the flamenco show. In most instances this would be acceptable but, when you are paying more than $200 per couple, it is fair to expect more. Additionally, while we were there, many in the audience were carrying on loud conversations and telephone calls. I understand that Corral De Moreria cannot be held responsible for their patrons' lack of manners however, it seems to me that some effort should be made to ask customers who are engaged in loud conversations during the show to either hang up their phones or conduct their conversations elsewhere so as not to disrupt performers nor the audience. So, to recap, the food was very good, the quality of the performers was excellent but the venue left a lot to be desired

title_review: Great Flamenco but too much disturbance over dinner with weird viewing angles
review_preview: It was a business trip to Madrid and all of went to see Flamenco at Corral de la Moreria. We had heard a lot about the place and the entire experience. It is expensive but was supposed to be worth the extra euros. Unfortunately, that...
review_full: It was a business trip to Madrid and all of went to see Flamenco at Corral de la Moreria. We had heard a lot about the place and the entire experience. It is expensive but was supposed to be worth the extra euros. Unfortunately, that was not really the case. The brilliant part is the actual performance. It was very, very good and the energy was just amazing. The performers were obviously very accomplished and their virtuosity was unbelievable. It was my first Flamenco performance in Spain and I was bowled over.  Everything else in the restaurant was a bit of a let down. Firstly, it is a super cramped place. Small chairs that give you barely enough place to sit comfortably. There are just too many diners packed in like sardines. It was a packed evening and the service was bad all the way. Whether it was the time taken between the different courses or having to remind someone to bring the olive oil, there seemed to be too few servers for the packed place. And then there is the angle from which the majority of guests have to view the dance - from pillars blocking the view to craning your neck to see the performance, it was just not the right viewing angle. Some of the tables have a direct, theatre-style view. But all others have a lateral view that is anything but optimal. Lastly, there is too much of disturbance during the performance, with servers floating around, people talking to each other, sounds of cutlery etc etc.  The restaurant itself is quite quaint and old. The food is quite good. It is a pity that the excellent performance gets diluted by other factors.

title_review: Quite outstanding local cuisine with great service and excellent wine
review_preview: Recommended by hotel concierge who had dined there one month before. A 20 minute walk from our Centro hotel but worth it. Atmospheric, you eat in the basement a former meat smoking area. Staff speak English and very welcoming and most helpful with suggestions as...
review_full: Recommended by hotel concierge who had dined there one month before. A 20 minute walk from our Centro hotel but worth it. Atmospheric, you eat in the basement a former meat smoking area. Staff speak English and very welcoming and most helpful with suggestions as regards food and wine. Wonderful , tomato salad, spicy chorizo and salted anchoivies followed by well cooked very tasty lamb and Iberian pork: they truly care as to the farms and fish markets they buy from. Red wine for its true class, Ribiero del Duero, great value Three course with cover ,wine and sparkling water with coffee and free liqueur about 110 euros for two. Exceptional value for a very memorable dinner cooked with best ingredients and served with intelligence but without formality. Well worth finding whilst in Madrid

review_preview: Arrived in Madrid after long flight from Australia and was looking for somewhere close to our digs. A quick TA search revealed La Mi Venta was highly regarded and very close so off we went. Centrally situated a stones throw from the Royal Palace with...
review_full: Arrived in Madrid after long flight from Australia and was looking for somewhere close to our digs. A quick TA search revealed La Mi Venta was highly regarded and very close so off we went. Centrally situated a stones throw from the Royal Palace with dining on the pavement inside the bar area and what looks like a very nice cellar. Staff were very attentive and tried hard to accomodate our poor Spanish by bringing out an English menu. We ordered a small selection of Tapa. That was, Cecina de Leon (cured beef), toasted bread with tomatoes, oil and garlic, Pisto Manchego (vegetable stew) from the extensive menu. However, we ordered a gin and tonic and a beer prior to this without realising that this triggers the supply of a couple of "pincho's" which I had noticed on the bar. Pincho's being small Tapa usually served on a disc of bread, two discs per drink per person. Our original food order was meant to be a start point but as we also had more drinks we soon were sated. We had five drinks but got three double portions of pincho's.  The main dishes were excellent and in particular the cured beef from Leon was the star, a new delight for me, I have had Bresceola in Aus but like the difference one may discover between Italian and Spanish hams so it seems with the air dried beef. Served with Padron Peppers and fried potatoes it was tops. The vegetable stew was as if made in a rustic kitchen and also a good eat and tomato bread is rarely a disappointment anywhere. The Gin and Tonic's were served in a small goldfish bowl and I don't think it would be advisable to drive after just one, house red was very pleasant. Hard to see us not going back for a second go. Oh and all this for under 50‚Ç¨.

review_preview: The place was very crowded with several large tour groups making it very hard to talk. At the large table directly behind us there was an extremely loud drunk blonde lady who was very obnoxious because of her volume. Across from her another lady became...
review_full: The place was very crowded with several large tour groups making it very hard to talk. At the large table directly behind us there was an extremely loud drunk blonde lady who was very obnoxious because of her volume. Across from her another lady became sick prior to the show and had to go out. She almost fainted on her way and had to sit down in a chair until one of the men in her group could escort her outside. She never returned. So it was not the best start for our evening. The view of the stage from our table was partially blocked by a pillar but not bad compared to several other tables. The dinner was surprisingly good. My wife had the rack of lamb with pumpkin puree and rustic potatoes while I had sea bass. For dessert my wife had a pear in wine with coffee cream while I had Cr√®me Brule. While the food was really very good I thought that given the relatively high prices paid for the show that the food prices were exhorbitant. But the experience shouldn't be missed.   The show was very good; more skillful, artistic, and expressive than the Flamenco show we had seen in Seville. There were two dancers, three singers, and two guitar players. It was all very exciting and we enjoyed our evening a lot. The dinner reservations had been for 7:30 pm with the early show beginning at 8:30 pm and ending about 9:40 pm. I would say this experience is a must if you are going to Spain. We were told by natives that these shows are too touristy and that we should look for small shows with fewer performers in Flamenco bars but we were very satisfied with our experience.

review_preview: After attending 3 flamenco shows at 3 different clubs in Seville the week before, we were excited to see flamenco in Madrid as we had heard some of the best performers head there to be on a larger scale. We went to El Corral as...
review_full: After attending 3 flamenco shows at 3 different clubs in Seville the week before, we were excited to see flamenco in Madrid as we had heard some of the best performers head there to be on a larger scale. We went to El Corral as it was highly rated on trip advisor...although we were pre-warned that it was expensive. We could not have been more disappointed!! Our first recommendation is to NEVER go to a flamenco show that has dinner included. There is too much"noise" occurring during the performance to enjoy it. The audience is disrespectful to the performers as they talk while the show is going on...also the waiters are running back and forth with plates and settling bills before the show is even concluded. This venue is just too large to appreciate a good show. That being said, this was not even a good flamenco. Comparing to what we saw in Seville where the artists are really into the music and do not even notice the audience and the audience gives the artists their undivided attention, these performers were more into the audience and pleasing them and looking for gratification. They were constantly looking at each other and not engrossing themselves in the music as we have seen previously. There was much less dancing than we were used to and there was much more singing...the dancers seemed to be much more interested in working their shawls than in working their feet. We know they rotate the performers and maybe we were there on a bad night...and maybe this place gets high reviews because it is the first place that someone sees flamenco, but it was well below what we have come to expect. As an aside, the food was good but very overpriced...and with one final note, this is a heavily touristed show, so it was surprising that the only long introduction given was entirely in Spanish, with no English translation. Pretty much all the people around us were non Spanish speaking and had no idea of what was said. In Seville, where English is spoken far less, even the smallest flamenco clubs would have someone who gave an English interpretation. We are going to another flamenco club tonight, which hopefully will restore our passion for this wondrous art form...

review_full: We ate in the small, back cellar room downstairs. Nice enough but was not a busy night so lacked atmosphere. Food was ok but nothing outstanding. 2 of us shared goatling at 40 euros, expected more than a plate of bones and meat for that price. Tasty enough but not good value. My son had the pork, really red pork, which was more like beef, but was very nice. My wife had hake cheeks, ok but a bit bony. All dishes were served with superb potatoes and lots of peppers. Wine was good, olive oil delicious. David is certainly a character, although some could find his style to be a bit over the top at times. Not sure we'd eat dinner there again but maybe tapas outside. Slightly overpriced in my opinion.

The first show of the evening was in progress at that time so we were shown to a small dining room just off the entry hall. Excellent menu with very high quality food very well presented . Dinner would have been worth it on its own and the combination worked very well. This dinner package gets you seats near the stage and food and drink service continues very efficiently during the show.

review_full: We've been there several times and always enjoyed excellent performance of flamenco. We think this is the best one in Madrid, considering the balance of all the elements of tablao, though it is also a very touristic place. Later stage might be better to enjoy more local feeling. We will surely go back there.

review_preview: Very touristic restaurant. You go for dinner and the flamenco dancers and musicians afterwards. Dinner is good served in a very exiguous dinning room.Not cheap though. The show is very good and thrilling. you can be touched by the artists when you fell the vibes...
review_full: Very touristic restaurant. You go for dinner and the flamenco dancers and musicians afterwards. Dinner is good served in a very exiguous dinning room.Not cheap though. The show is very good and thrilling. you can be touched by the artists when you fell the vibes and believe me you can certainly do in that small dinning room. Very talented artists.Very nice evening in Madrid
